N.J. -- U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nNot surprisingly, this out of the blue announcement came as a surprise to Venezuela and prompted a predictable response:\n\nPresident Trump's remarks on Friday that he would not rule out a \"military option\" to quell the chaos in Venezuela set off a late-night diplomatic duel, with the defense minister accusing Mr. Trump of \"an act of madness\" and the White House saying it had turned away a call from Venezuela's president.\n\n\"It is an act of supreme extremism,\" Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino L\u00f3pez said late Friday in Caracas, the capital.\n\n\"As our minister of defense and a Venezuelan citizen,\" he added, \"I say it is an act of madness.\"\n\nAbout an hour later, the White House issued a statement saying that Mr. Trump had refused to take a phone call on Friday from Venezuela's president, Nicol\u00e1s Maduro.\n\n\"Today, Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with President Donald J. Trump,\" the White House said. \"President Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nVenezuelan officials did not confirm the White House's account of the phone call. They seemed shocked that Mr. Trump had mentioned their country -- troubled for weeks by protests and charges of election fraud -- alongside a nuclear-armed North Korea.\n\nThe Venezuelan communications minister, Ernesto Villegas, in a television interview, called Mr. Trump's remark \"an unprecedented threat to national sovereignty.\"\n\nMr. Padrino did not indicate how Venezuela would officially respond to the comments by Mr. Trump, who said, \"Venezuela is not very far away, and the people are suffering, and they're dying.\"\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option, if necessary,\" Mr. Trump said.\n\nThe defense minister said to expect a more detailed diplomatic response on Saturday.\n\nThe situation in Venezuela is one that has been getting seemingly worse as time has gone along. Thanks largely to the socialist policies put into effect by the late Hugo Chavez and continued by his successor, the country's economy is an absolute mess notwithstanding the fact that it continues to be sustained by revenues from the sale of oil, although the revenue it garners from natural resources has plummeted in recent years thanks to the sustained decline in oil prices that seems irreversible at the moment. Food shortages have become commonplace, for example, as have shortages of everyday item such as toilet paper and other basic needs. Additionally, President Nicholas Maduro has proven to be every bit as repressive to opposition parties as his predecessor and role model was if not more so. In recent months, this has led to marches in the streets and an increasingly vocal civilian opposition that is being met with violent repression by Venezuelan authorities. Recently, there have been events that have suggested that the Venezuelan military may be prepared to take matters into its own hands and overthrow the Maduro regime. This has included an incident in June involving a stolen police helicopter that attacked several government buildings in Caracas and elsewhere in the country, and what was described as a \"terrorist\" attack on a Venezuelan military base last week. Additionally, the aforementioned opposition protests have become increasingly violent, with police and military forces not holding back against people who are clearly frustrated with the extent more than a decade of rule under the Chavez/Maduro regime. At some point, the country seems likely to either descend into further chaos or overthrow Maduro and begin the process of recovering what should be a nation flourishing thanks to more than ample energy reserves.\n\nGiven that this is Trump we're talking about, it's hard to tell if his talk of a 'military option' is serious or not. This is, after all, a man with a long history of making boastful claims and threats that never come to pass, whether we're talking about his claims about the President's birth certificate or his promise to a rather idiotic promise to build a border wall that Mexico will pay for. Trump isn't making these statements as the D-List Celebrity he used to be, though, he's making them as President of the United States. This means that we are required to take what he says seriously, and the fact that he's saying something like this is rather alarming both because of the fact that he's threatening to get the U.S. military involved in what seems to be a situation that is headed down the road to civil war and because it is utterly without merit and wholly irresponsible.\n\nTo put it bluntly, there is nothing going on in Venezuela that would justify the use of American military force to intervene in the country. Thanks to years of economic and diplomatic sanctions there are apparently very few Americans even left in the country and those who are there are connected to the country's energy sector which, at least for now, has managed to escape any targeting by either the government or opposition forces. The Venezuelan military itself is far too small to pose a serious threat to the United States or any of its neighbors, and in any case is far too involved in trying to keep the increasingly discredited Maduro regime in power to be much of a problem for anyone else in the world. Trump's rhetoric, therefore, is nothing but blustering nonsense from a man who probably couldn't find Venezuela on a map if one of his advisers didn't point it out to him.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T14:50:00Z", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "source": {"uri": "outsidethebeltway.com", "title": "outsidethebeltway.com", "id": "451"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:50:00", "url": "http://www.outsidethebeltway.com/trump-suggests-military-option-in-venezula/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8806334", "image": "http://www.outsidethebeltway.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/03/Trump-Speech-Congress-570x428.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "14:50:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for US officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. McMaster to speak to members of the media following their meeting at Trump National Golf Club in Bedminster, N.J., Friday. Pablo Martinez Monsivais -- The Associated Press\n\nWASHINGTON >> President Donald Trump has said he wouldn't rule out military action against Venezuela in response to the country's descent into political chaos following President Nicolas Maduro's power grab. Venezuela's government responded by accusing Trump of seeking to destabilize Latin America.\n\nSpeaking to reporters Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table -- including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region.\n\nVenezuela's government responded Saturday in a statement read by Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza that called Trump's talk of a potential military option an act of belligerence and a threat to Latin America's stability.\n\nThe White House released a statement Friday evening saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela -- the third-largest supplier to the U.S. -- would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly expanded Panama Canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last weekend on MSNBC.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug off the accusations as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defense Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\nGoodman reported from Caracas, Venezuela. Associated Press writer Lolita C. Baldor in Washington contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T22:25:00Z", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "source": {"uri": "news-herald.com", "title": "Willoughby News-Herald", "id": "3079"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "22:25:00", "url": "http://www.news-herald.com/article/HR/20170812/NEWS/170819829", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8850114", "image": "http://www.news-herald.com/apps/pbcsi.dll/storyimage/HR/20170812/NEWS/170819829/AR/0/AR-170819829.jpg?Maxh=900&Maxw=900", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "22:25:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\nU.S. President Donald Trump speaks to reporters after meeting with Secretary of State Rex Tillerson, U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley and National Security Adviser H.R. McMaster at Trump's golf estate in Bedminster, New Jersey U.S. August 11, 2017.Jonathan Ernst\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.\n\n______________________________________________\n\nWhy is Trump pissing off a guy what can cut off our supply of petroleum and destabilize the world markets?", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 2279, "textStart": 2264}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T17:29:00Z", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "source": {"uri": "haitian-truth.org", "title": "haitian-truth.org", "id": "15972"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:29:00", "url": "http://www.haitian-truth.org/more-american-ignorance-what-about-article-17-of-the-oas-chartertrump-threatens-venezuela-with-unspecified-military-option/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8823060", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "17:29:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Donald Trump\n\nUS President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\" Venezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defence Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said US officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the US military was ready to support efforts to protect US citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned US invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nA Car is torched amid protests in Venezuela\n\nAsked if US forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticised Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorising war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\n'MADURO MUST BE THRILLED'\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 2, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "WASHINGTON: US President Donald Trump has said that he would not rule out the possibility of a military intervention in Venezuela in response to the South American nations descent into political chaos, the media reported.\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump deplored Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table, including a potential military intervention, reports The Washington Post.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump said.\n\n\"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\n\n\"This is our neighbour. You know, we are all over the world and we have troops all over the world in places that are very, very far away. Venezuela is not very far away and the people are suffering, and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option if necessary,\" the President added.\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped sanctions on Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro after a July 30 vote that allowed him to replace the opposition-held National Assembly with a new 545-member Constituent Assembly (ANC) filled with his supporters escalating fears of turning the country into dictatorship, reports CNN.\n\nTrump's comments came after a meeting at his golf club with US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson.\n\nIn response, Venezuela's Defence Minister Gen. Vladimir Padrino called Trump's talk of a military intervention an act of \"craziness\" and \"supreme extremism\", The Washington Post reported.\n\nPadrino, a close ally of Maduro, said: \"With this extremist elite that's in charge in the US, who knows what will happen to the world?\"\n\nMeanwhile, the White House on Friday night issued a statement saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump.\n\nThe statement said: \"The US stands with the people of Venezuela in the face of their continued oppression by the Maduro regime.\n\n\"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nVenezuela has been marred in a deepening economic crisis and political stalemate.\n\nSince Maduro announced the formation of the ANC in April, violent nationwide protests have taken place resulting in the deaths of over 100 people.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-07-30", "textEnd": 1107, "textStart": 1100}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T03:38:00Z", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "source": {"uri": "newindianexpress.com", "title": "The New Indian Express", "id": "934"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:38:00", "url": "http://www.newindianexpress.com/world/2017/aug/12/wont-rule-out-military-option-in-venezuela-us-president-donald-trump-1642135.html", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8739136", "image": "http://images.newindianexpress.com/uploads/user/imagelibrary/2017/8/11/w600X390/donald-trump-trump-tower-press-conference-AP-640x480.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "03:38:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/New_Jersey", "id": "216558"}, {"label": {"eng": "Donald Trump"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Donald_Trump", "score": 4, "id": "302942", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "The Pentagon"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pentagon", "score": 1, "id": "303092", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nicol\u00e1s Maduro"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicol\u00e1s_Maduro", "score": 4, "id": "304337", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Latin America"}, "type": "loc", "score": 5, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_America", "id": "304656"}, {"label": {"eng": "Petroleum"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petroleum", "score": 3, "id": "305421", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Latin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin", "score": 5, "id": "311427", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jorge Arreaza"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Arreaza", "score": 3, "id": "333141", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Panama Canal"}, "type": "loc", "score": 2, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama_Canal", "id": "336919"}], "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - President Donald Trump has said he wouldn't rule out military action against Venezuela in response to the country's descent into political chaos following President Nicolas Maduro's power grab. Venezuela's government responded by accusing Trump of seeking to destabilize Latin America.\n\nSpeaking to reporters Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table - including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region.\n\nVenezuela's government responded Saturday in a statement read by Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza that called Trump's talk of a potential military option an act of belligerence and a threat to Latin America's stability.\n\nThe White House released a statement Friday evening saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela - the third-largest supplier to the U.S. - would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly expanded Panama Canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last weekend on MSNBC.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug off the accusations as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defense Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n__\n\nGoodman reported from Caracas, Venezuela. Associated Press writer Lolita C. Baldor in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. {"eng": "List of Presidents of Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "US President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said US officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the US military was ready to support efforts to protect US citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned US invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if US forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation, a military option, is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe US military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former US president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, US Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T08:46:00Z", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "source": {"uri": "egyptindependent.com", "title": "egyptindependent.com", "id": "1817"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:46:00", "url": "http://www.egyptindependent.com/trump-threatens-venezuela-unspecified-military-option/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8766661", "image": "http://www.egyptindependent.com/app/uploads/sites/default/files/photo/2017/01/30/507556/donald_trump_angel.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "08:46:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

(Reuters) - U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbours to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. "333141", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Panama Canal"}, "type": "loc", "score": 2, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama_Canal", "id": "336919"}, {"label": {"eng": "H. R. McMaster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._R._McMaster", "score": 2, "id": "917917", "type": "person"}], "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - President Donald Trump has said he wouldn't rule out military action against Venezuela in response to the country's descent into political chaos following President Nicolas Maduro's power grab. Venezuela's government responded by accusing Trump of seeking to destabilize Latin America.\n\nSpeaking to reporters Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table -- including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region.\n\nVenezuela's government responded Saturday in a statement read by Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza that called Trump's talk of a potential military option an act of belligerence and a threat to Latin America's stability.\n\nThe White House released a statement Friday evening saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela -- the third-largest supplier to the U.S. -- would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly expanded Panama Canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last weekend on MSNBC.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug off the accusations as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defense Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T03:39:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"uri": "hamodia.com", "title": "Hamodia", "id": "3374"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:39:00", "url": "http://hamodia.com/2017/08/12/trump-says-hes-open-military-intervention-venezuela/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8868374", "image": "http://images.hamodia.com/hamod-uploads/2017/08/AP17223820458270-300x233.jpg", "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "03:39:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness\".\n\nVenezuela has opposition-controlled congress.\n\nALSO READ:\n\nWorld continues to watch Venezuela with apathy\n\nUS hits Venezuela with new sanctions\n\nMaduro vows 'maximum penalty' for attack on Venezuela base\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness\".\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said US officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the US military was ready to support efforts to protect US citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned US invasion were \"baseless\". Trump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if US forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation -- a military option -- is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticised Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorising war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for US officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. {"eng": "List of Presidents of Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness\".\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session. The comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless\".\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if the U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation -- a military option -- is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance. \"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today,\" he added.\n\n'MADURO MUST BE THRILLED'\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender. \"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. President Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\" he said.\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. out the possibility of a military intervention in Venezuela in response to the South American nations descent into political chaos, the media reported.\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump deplored Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table, including a potential military intervention, reports The Washington Post.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump said.\n\n\"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\n\n\"This is our neighbour. You know, we are all over the world and we have troops all over the world in places that are very, very far away. Venezuela is not very far away and the people are suffering, and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option if necessary,\" the President added.\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped sanctions on Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro after a July 30 vote that allowed him to replace the opposition-held National Assembly with a new 545-member Constituent Assembly (ANC) filled with his supporters escalating fears of turning the country into dictatorship, reports CNN.\n\nTrump's comments came after a meeting at his golf club with US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson.\n\nIn response, Venezuela's Defence Minister Gen. Vladimir Padrino called Trump's talk of a military intervention an act of \"craziness\" and \"supreme extremism\", The Washington Post reported.\n\nPadrino, a close ally of Maduro, said: \"With this extremist elite that's in charge in the US, who knows what will happen to the world?\"\n\nMeanwhile, the White House on Friday night issued a statement saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump.\n\nThe statement said: \"The US stands with the people of Venezuela in the face of their continued oppression by the Maduro regime.\n\n\"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nVenezuela has been marred in a deepening economic crisis and political stalemate.\n\nSince Maduro announced the formation of the ANC in April, violent nationwide protests have taken place resulting in the deaths of over 100 people.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Business Standard staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-07-30", "textEnd": 1095, "textStart": 1088}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T03:38:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"uri": "business-standard.com", "title": "Business Standard", "id": "405"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:38:00", "url": "http://www.business-standard.com/article/news-ians/won-t-rule-out-military-option-in-venezuela-trump-117081200110_1.html", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8739118", "image": "http://bsmedia.business-standard.com/_media/bs/img/common/no_preview.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "03:38:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"body": "WASHINGTON - President Donald Trump has said he wouldn't rule out military action against Venezuela in response to the country's descent into political chaos following President Nicolas Maduro's power grab. Venezuela's government responded by accusing Trump of seeking to destabilize Latin America.\n\nSpeaking to reporters Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table -- including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice-President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region.\n\nVenezuela's government responded Saturday in a statement read by Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza that called Trump's talk of a potential military option an act of belligerence and a threat to Latin America's stability.\n\nThe White House released a statement Friday evening saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela -- the third-largest supplier to the U.S. -- would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly expanded Panama Canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbours to speak with a single voice in defence of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last weekend on MSNBC.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug off the accusations as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defence Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n__\n\nGoodman reported from Caracas, Venezuela. Associated Press writer Lolita C. Baldor in Washington contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T18:41:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"uri": "mymcmurray.com", "title": "MyMcMurray", "id": "1171"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:41:00", "url": "http://www.mymcmurray.com/2017/08/12/trump-says-hes-open-to-military-intervention-in-venezuela/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8830762", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "18:41:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "President Donald Trump threatened military intervention in Venezuela Friday, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has slid toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nDaily Emails and Alerts - Get the best of Newsweek delivered to your inbox\n\nFlames erupt as clashes break out near security forces members (R) while the Constituent Assembly election is being carried out in Caracas, Venezuela, July 30, 2017. REUTERS/Carlos Garcia Rawlins\n\nThe comments came as shock news to Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nPadrino, as quoted by ABC News, told state television: \"It is an act of supreme extremism. There is an extremist elite that rules the United States.\"\n\n\"As a soldier, I stand with the Venezuelan armed forces, and with the people.\n\n\"I am sure that we will all be on the frontlines of defending the interests and sovereignty of this beloved Venezuela.\"\n\nCommunications Minister Ernesto Villegas said it was \"an unprecedented threat to national sovereignty.\"\n\nThe \"diplomatic corps is summoned to the foreign ministry for [Saturday], when it will release a communique addressing the imperial threat to Venezuela.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's military stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" southern neighbors as underlings who could easily be intimidated through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove a military government from Haiti installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-07-30", "textEnd": 867, "textStart": 854}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T10:49:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"uri": "newsweek.com", "title": "Newsweek", "id": "14218"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:04:00", "url": "http://www.newsweek.com/venezuelan-defence-chief-calls-trump-military-threat-unprecedented-craziness-650082", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8788329", "image": "http://s.newsweek.com/sites/www.newsweek.com/files/styles/full/public/2017/08/11/donald-trump-speaks.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "10:49:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "By: Reuters | Bedminster | Updated: August 12, 2017 8:15 am U.S. President Donald Trump, flanked by Secretary of State Rex Tillerson (L) and U.S. Ambassador to the United Nations Nikki Haley (R) speaks to reporters after their meeting at Trump's golf estate in Bedminster, New Jersey U.S. August 11, 2017. REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst US President Donald Trump says he wasn't being serious in remarks about PutinDonald Trump says U.S. is 'locked and loaded' in North Korea confrontationNorth Korea threat: 'Take cover, avoid bomb flash'- Guam issues nuclear guidelines\n\nU.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\" Venezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\n'MADURO MUST BE THRILLED'\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.\n\nFor all the latest World News, download Indian Express App\n\nTags: donald trump", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 51, "textStart": 36}, {"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 304, "textStart": 289}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "source": {"uri": "indianexpress.com", "title": "The Indian Express", "id": "1155"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:50:00", "url": "http://indianexpress.com/article/world/us-president-donald-trump-threatens-venezuela-with-unspecified-military-option-4792974/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8735370", "image": "http://images.indianexpress.com/2017/08/donald-trump-7591.jpg?w=759", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:50:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}
