conference outside his Bedminster resort on Friday evening, President Donald Trump suggested the US was weighing military options in response to ongoing turmoil in Venezuela.\n\nAsked about the US response to the political, economic, and social crises in the South American country, Trump said, \"We have many options for Venezuela, and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option.\"\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela. This is our neighbor ... this is -- we're all over the world, and we have troops all over the world in places that are very, very far away,\" Trump added. \"Venezuela is not very far away, and the people are suffering, and they're dying. We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option, if necessary.\"\n\nAsked if it would be a US-led military operation, Trump said, \"We don't talk about it, but a military operation, a military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\n\"I support peace. I support safety, and I support having to get tough if we have to\" in order to protect Americans and people around the world, the president added.\n\nAfter Trump's remarks, the Pentagon said that it had not gotten any orders on Venezuela from the White House, according to Idrees Ali of Reuters. The Pentagon added that, \"Any insinuations by the Maduro regime that we are planning an invasion are baseless.\"\n\n(Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro at a pro-government rally with workers of state-run oil company PDVSA, in Barcelona, Venezuela, July 8, 2017.Thomson Reuters)\n\nThe US has already issued three rounds of sanctions against Venezuela officials since the end of July.\n\nThirteen officials were sanctioned during the last week July, ahead of the vote to elect members to a widely condemned constituent assembly that critics charge is a government maneuver to consolidate power by President Nicolas Maduro. After the vote on July 30, the US sanctioned Maduro himself, and this week the US Treasury announced sanctions against eight more officials.\n\nVenezuela is now in the fifth month of a period of protests that broke out in early April, after the supreme court, considered by many to aligned with Maduro, attempted to strip the opposition-led National Assembly of its powers.\n\nThe supreme court backed off that effort, but the often violent protests that have taken place since have left at least 120 people dead, the majority of them anti-government demonstrators, and led to thousands of arrests.\n\nThis week, 17 countries from the region condemned the \"breakdown of democratic order\" in Venezuela and said they would not recognize the constituent assembly or any measures it may pass regarding future joint oil ventures or debt matters.\n\n(A demonstrator is detained at a rally during a strike called to protest against Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro's government in Caracas.Thomson Reuters)\n\nTrump administration officials have previously said all options are on the table\" to penalize Maduro and his government, including import or export bans on Venezuelan oil or sanctions on the state-run oil company, Pdvsa.\n\nA number of experts as well as US businesses have urged caution with sanctions on the oil industry. Venezuela gets about 95% of its export revenue from oil, and a reduction of that could hinder its ability to buy imported food and medicine, adding to the humanitarian crisis in the country.\n\nRead More\n\nVenezuela is also the US's third-largest oil supplier, and sanctions on that oil could affect jobs and gas prices in the US.\n\nVenezuela under Maduro and his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, has had contentious relations with the US and the two countries have not had ambassadors since 2010.\n\nOn Thursday, Maduro said Venezuela \"will never give in\" but also appealed for a meeting with Trump, who has called the Venezuelan president a \"dictator.\"\n\nDuring an address to the new, all-powerful constitutional assembly, Maduro told his foreign minister to approach the US about a telephone conversation or meeting with Trump.\n\n\"Mr. Donald Trump, here is my hand,\" Maduro said, adding that he wants as strong a relationship with the US as he has with Russia.\n\nYou can see a clip of "body": "Washington, Aug 12 (IANS) US President Donald Trump has said that he would not rule out the possibility of a military intervention in Venezuela in response to the South American nations descent into political chaos, the media reported.\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump deplored Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table, including a potential military intervention, reports The Washington Post.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump said.\n\n\"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\n\n\"This is our neighbour. You know, we are all over the world and we have troops all over the world in places that are very, very far away. Venezuela is not very far away and the people are suffering, and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option if necessary,\" the President added.\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped sanctions on Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro after a July 30 vote that allowed him to replace the opposition-held National Assembly with a new 545-member Constituent Assembly (ANC) filled with his supporters escalating fears of turning the country into dictatorship, reports CNN.\n\nTrump's comments came after a meeting at his golf club with US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson.\n\nIn response, Venezuela's Defence Minister Gen. Vladimir Padrino called Trump's talk of a military intervention an act of \"craziness\" and \"supreme extremism\", The Washington Post reported.\n\nPadrino, a close ally of Maduro, said: \"With this extremist elite that's in charge in the US, who knows what will happen to the world?\"\n\nMeanwhile, the White House on Friday night issued a statement saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump.\n\nThe statement said: \"The US stands with the people of Venezuela in the face of their continued oppression by the Maduro regime.\n\n\"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nVenezuela has been marred in a deepening economic crisis and political stalemate.\n\nSince Maduro announced the formation of the ANC in April, violent nationwide protests have taken place resulting in the deaths of over 100 people.\n\n--IANS\n\nksk\n\nSEARCH", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 18, "textStart": 12}, {"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-07-30", "textEnd": 1121, "textStart": 1114}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T04:09:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"uri": "sify.com", "title": "Sify", "id": "186"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "04:09:00", "url": "http://www.sify.com/news/wont-rule-out-military-option-in-venezuela-trump-news-others-rimiXRigfghge.html", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8741377", "image": "http://static.sify.com/cms/commons/widget/images/featured-thumbs-default-img.gif", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "04:09:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Venezuela's government responded by accusing Trump of seeking to destabilize Latin America.\n\nSpeaking to reporters Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table -- including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region.\n\nVenezuela's government responded Saturday in a statement read by Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza that called Trump's talk of a potential military option an act of belligerence and a threat to Latin America's stability.\n\nThe White House released a statement Friday evening saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela -- the third-largest supplier to the U.S. -- would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly expanded Panama Canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last weekend on MSNBC.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug off the accusations as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defense Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-10", "textEnd": 159, "textStart": 146}, {"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 238, "textStart": 225}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T20:44:00Z", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "source": {"uri": "lasvegassun.com", "title": "LasVegasSun.com", "id": "1295"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "20:44:00", "url": "https://lasvegassun.com/news/2017/aug/12/trump-says-hes-open-to-military-intervention-in-ve/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8841911", "image": "http://photos.lasvegassun.com/media/img/photos/2017/08/10/AP17222678499080_t600.jpg?42b0fb247f69dabe2ae440581a34634cbc5420f3", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "20:44:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_America", "id": "304656"}, {"label": {"eng": "OPEC"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/OPEC", "score": 2, "id": "308346", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Bolivarian Intelligence Service"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolivarian_Intelligence_Service", "score": 2, "id": "364132", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Gunboat diplomacy"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunboat_diplomacy", "score": 2, "id": "498474", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Man-portable air-defense systems"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man-portable_air-defense_systems", "score": 1, "id": "540414", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of Presidents of Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 2, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation in Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis.\n\nU.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation in Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis. Venezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress. \"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters.\n\nMore than 120 people have been killed in Venezuela and thousands arrested in over four months of unrest. The government in Caracas did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Trump's threat.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\n\"MADURO MUST BE THRILLED\"\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's comments could be an asset to Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T00:44:00Z", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "source": {"uri": "financialexpress.com", "title": "The Financial Express", "id": "4684"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "00:44:00", "url": "http://www.financialexpress.com/world-news/donald-trump-threatens-venezuela-with-unspecified-military-option/805025/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8725905", "image": "http://images.financialexpress.com/2017/08/download-4-6.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "00:44:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\n'MADURO MUST BE THRILLED'\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {"liCnt": 3}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:55:00Z", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "title": "The Globe and Mail", "id": "1409"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:18:00", "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/trump-considers-military-option-in-response-to-venezuela/article35970340/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8733113", "image": "https://static.theglobeandmail.ca/be8/news/world/article35970339.ece/ALTERNATES/w620/web-nw-wo-trump-venezuela-0.JPG", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:55:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"score": 3, "id": "366831", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Gunboat diplomacy"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunboat_diplomacy", "score": 2, "id": "498474", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of Presidents of Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Washington, 12 August 2017 (MIA) - U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness\", Reuters reports.\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council. ik/10:50\n\n###\n\nAll Rights Reserved.This material may not be stored, published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed in any form, except with the prior express permission of Macedonian Information Agency.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 26, "textStart": 12}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T08:55:00Z", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "source": {"uri": "mia.mk", "title": "MIA", "id": "18788"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:55:00", "url": "http://www.mia.mk/en/Inside/RenderSingleNews/314/133813424", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8767755", "image": "http://www.mia.mk/File/Picture/133270298/picture.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "08:55:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Petroleum"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petroleum", "score": 3, "id": "305421", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Latin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin", "score": 5, "id": "311427", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jorge Arreaza"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Arreaza", "score": 3, "id": "333141", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Panama Canal"}, "type": "loc", "score": 2, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama_Canal", "id": "336919"}], "body": "By Jill Colvin And Joshua Goodman, The Associated Press on August 12, 2017.\n\nWASHINGTON - President Donald Trump has said he wouldn't rule out military action against Venezuela in response to the country's descent into political chaos following President Nicolas Maduro's power grab. Venezuela's government responded by accusing Trump of seeking to destabilize Latin America.\n\nSpeaking to reporters Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table - including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice-President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region.\n\nVenezuela's government responded Saturday in a statement read by Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza that called Trump's talk of a potential military option an act of belligerence and a threat to Latin America's stability.\n\nThe White House released a statement Friday evening saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela - the third-largest supplier to the U.S. - would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly expanded Panama Canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbours to speak with a single voice in defence of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last weekend on MSNBC.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug off the accusations as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defence Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n__\n\nGoodman reported from Caracas, Venezuela. Associated Press writer Lolita C. Baldor in Washington contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 74, "textStart": 59}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T18:36:00Z", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "source": {"uri": "medicinehatnews.com", "title": "Medicine Hat News", "id": "5619"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:36:00", "url": "http://medicinehatnews.com/news/world-news/2017/08/12/trump-says-hes-open-to-military-intervention-in-venezuela/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8829627", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "18:36:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Donald Trump has said he wouldn't rule out military action against Venezuela in response to the country's descent into political chaos following President Nicolas Maduro's power grab. Venezuela's government responded by accusing Trump of seeking to destabilize Latin America.\n\nSpeaking to reporters Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table -- including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region.\n\nVenezuela's government responded Saturday in a statement read by Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza that called Trump's talk of a potential military option an act of belligerence and a threat to Latin America's stability.\n\nThe White House released a statement Friday evening saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela -- the third-largest supplier to the U.S. -- would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly expanded Panama Canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last weekend on MSNBC.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug off the accusations as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defense Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n__\n\nGoodman reported from Caracas, Venezuela. Associated Press writer Lolita C. Baldor in Washington contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T17:32:00Z", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "source": {"uri": "hosted2.ap.org", "title": "Associated Press", "id": "566"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "17:55:00", "url": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CARIE/6b85546689744819aa7a64cd3ca6cee6/Article_2017-08-12-US--United%20States-Venezuela/id-23a545e0cd664e5d82569984472aa83c", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8825947", "image": "http://hosted2.ap.org/CBImages/?media=photo&contentId=5155928a69774c5aa73129c943ae8c16&fmt=jpg&Role=Preview&reldt=2017-08-11T22:19:50GMT&authToken=eNoNwbsNwCAMBcCJLAX%2fX8EwlkVBlzIFw4e7s77p4pKs4vxcDtXTe9owA2eRI4K0rahCBjEaKrWyh5%2f9Ts5QBNh%2f0CgS%2bg%3d%3d", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "17:32:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "BEDMINSTER, NEW JERSEY (REUTERS) - US President Donald Trump on Friday (Aug 11) threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness\".\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide towards a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defence Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness\".\n\nGet The Straits Times\n\nnewsletters in your inboxSign Up\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said US officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the US military was ready to support efforts to protect US citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned US invasion were \"baseless\".\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if US forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\n'MADURO MUST BE THRILLED'\n\nThe President's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the US regarded its \"backyard\" neighbours to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe US military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former US president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe US sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the Opec member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made Manpads surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for US officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the US. At the time, US Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 78, "textStart": 72}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T03:32:00Z", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "source": {"uri": "straitstimes.com", "title": "The Straits Times", "id": "611"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:32:00", "url": "http://www.straitstimes.com/world/americas/trump-threatens-venezuela-with-unspecified-military-option", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8738583", "image": "http://www.straitstimes.com/sites/default/files/media-youtube/fPA4nK1HZPQ.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "03:32:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"305421", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Latin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin", "score": 5, "id": "311427", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Jorge Arreaza"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jorge_Arreaza", "score": 3, "id": "333141", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Panama Canal"}, "type": "loc", "score": 2, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama_Canal", "id": "336919"}], "body": "By Jill Colvin And Joshua Goodman, The Associated Press on August 12, 2017.\n\nWASHINGTON - President Donald Trump has said he wouldn't rule out military action against Venezuela in response to the country's descent into political chaos following President Nicolas Maduro's power grab. Venezuela's government responded by accusing Trump of seeking to destabilize Latin America.\n\nSpeaking to reporters Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table - including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice-President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region.\n\nVenezuela's government responded Saturday in a statement read by Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza that called Trump's talk of a potential military option an act of belligerence and a threat to Latin America's stability.\n\nThe White House released a statement Friday evening saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela - the third-largest supplier to the U.S. - would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly expanded Panama Canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbours to speak with a single voice in defence of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last weekend on MSNBC.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug off the accusations as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defence Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n__\n\nGoodman reported from Caracas, Venezuela. Associated Press writer Lolita C. Baldor in Washington contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-12", "textEnd": 74, "textStart": 59}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T18:08:00Z", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "source": {"uri": "lethbridgeherald.com", "title": "lethbridgeherald.com", "id": "6076"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "18:08:00", "url": "http://lethbridgeherald.com/news/world-news/2017/08/12/trump-says-hes-open-to-military-intervention-in-venezuela/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8826947", "image": "http://lethbridgeherald.com/wp-content/uploads/cp/NJPM116-811_2017_230335.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "18:08:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"score": 3, "id": "366831", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Gunboat diplomacy"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gunboat_diplomacy", "score": 2, "id": "498474", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of Presidents of Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "BEDMINSTER, N.J. (Reuters) - U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\n'MADURO MUST BE THRILLED'\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbours to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.\n\n(Reporting by James Oliphant; Additional reporting by Hugh Bronstein and Girish Gupta in Caracas; Writing by Jason Lange in Washington; Editing by Andrew Hay and Mary Milliken)", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:37:00Z", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "source": {"uri": "thestar.com.my", "title": "The Star Online", "id": "334"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:37:00", "url": "http://www.thestar.com.my/news/world/2017/08/12/trump-threatens-venezuela-with-military-option/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8734427", "image": "http://www.thestar.com.my/~/media/online/2017/08/12/00/16/20170812t001506z_1_lynxmped7b005_rtroptp_3_usatrump.ashx/", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:37:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 2, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation in Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis.\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after the installation of an all-powerful new legislative body.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters.\n\nMore than 120 people have been killed in Venezuela and thousands arrested in over four months of unrest. The government in Caracas did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Trump's threat.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said it had not received any orders on Venezuela from the White House. Trump, asked if U.S. forces would lead any operation in Venezuela, declined to provide details.\n\n\"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" Trump said.\n\nThe United States sanctioned Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro and other Venezuelan officials on July 31 after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It is the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America and a source of concern for U.S. officials amid the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-07-31", "textEnd": 1420, "textStart": 1413}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {"gpCnt": 5}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T23:51:00Z", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "source": {"uri": "theglobeandmail.com", "title": "The Globe and Mail", "id": "1409"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "23:51:00", "url": "https://www.theglobeandmail.com/news/world/trump-considers-possible-military-option-in-response-to-venezuela/article35970340/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8721215", "image": "https://static.theglobeandmail.ca/be8/news/world/article35970339.ece/ALTERNATES/w620/web-nw-wo-trump-venezuela-0.JPG", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "23:51:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-11"}

"id": "311427", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Panama Canal"}, "type": "loc", "score": 3, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama_Canal", "id": "336919"}, {"label": {"eng": "Bolivarian Intelligence Service"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolivarian_Intelligence_Service", "score": 3, "id": "364132", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "H. R. McMaster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._R._McMaster", "score": 2, "id": "917917", "type": "person"}], "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) - President Donald Trump said Friday that he wouldn't rule out military action against Venezuela in response to the country's descent into political chaos following President Nicolas Maduro's power grab.\n\nSpeaking to reporters at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned the country's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table - including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region later this week.\n\nVenezuela's defense minister called Trump's talk of a military intervention an act of \"craziness\" and \"supreme extremism.\"\n\nGen. Vladimir Padrino, a close ally of Maduro, said, \"With this extremist elite that's in charge in the U.S., who knows what will happen to the world?\"\n\nThe White House later released a statement saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela - the third-largest supplier to the U.S. - would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly-expanded Panama canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\n\"The Vice President's trip will highlight the divide between the past and present of Latin America,\" said Jarrod Agen, a Pence spokesman, in a statement sent before Trump's comments. \"Venezuela represents the past, with the failed path of tyranny and oppression, but Colombia, Argentina, Chile and Panama represent the future of freedom, opportunity and prosperity.\"\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\n\"You've seen Maduro have some lame attempts to try to do that already,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last Saturday on MSNBC.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" he said.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug the accusations off as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nIn eastern Caracas, the center of months of deadly anti-government protests, residents reacted with a mix of disbelief and frustration with Trump's remarks, which they fear will embolden the weakened Maduro and distract attention from his abuses.\n\n\"Of course we don't support violence, but look at all the violence we're already suffering,\" said Irali Medina, an office administrator, pointing to the spot where a university student was killed recently by a tear gas canister fired by national guardsmen controlling protesters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defense Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n__\n\nGoodman reported from Caracas, Venezuela. Associated Press writer Lolita C. Baldor in Washington contributed to this report.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. deplored Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table, including a potential military intervention, reports The Washington Post.\n\nUS President Donald Trump has said that he would not rule out the possibility of a military intervention in Venezuela in response to the South American nations descent into political chaos, the media reported. Speaking to reporters on Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump deplored Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table, including a potential military intervention, reports The Washington Post. \"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump said. \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue. \"This is our neighbour. You know, we are all over the world and we have troops all over the world in places that are very, very far away. Venezuela is not very far away and the people are suffering, and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option if necessary,\" the President added.\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped sanctions on Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro after a July 30 vote that allowed him to replace the opposition-held National Assembly with a new 545-member Constituent Assembly (ANC) filled with his supporters escalating fears of turning the country into dictatorship, reports CNN. Trump's comments came after a meeting at his golf club with US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson.\n\nIn response, Venezuela's Defence Minister Gen. Vladimir Padrino called Trump's talk of a military intervention an act of \"craziness\" and \"supreme extremism\", The Washington Post reported. "302942", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "The Pentagon"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/The_Pentagon", "score": 1, "id": "303092", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nicol\u00e1s Maduro"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicol\u00e1s_Maduro", "score": 4, "id": "304337", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Latin America"}, "type": "loc", "score": 4, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_America", "id": "304656"}, {"label": {"eng": "Petroleum"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petroleum", "score": 3, "id": "305421", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Latin"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin", "score": 5, "id": "311427", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Panama Canal"}, "type": "loc", "score": 2, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama_Canal", "id": "336919"}, {"label": {"eng": "Bolivarian Intelligence Service"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolivarian_Intelligence_Service", "score": 3, "id": "364132", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "H. R. McMaster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._R._McMaster", "score": 2, "id": "917917", "type": "person"}], "body": "WASHINGTON -- President Donald Trump said Friday that he wouldn't rule out military action against Venezuela in response to the country's descent into political chaos following President Nicolas Maduro's power grab.\n\nSpeaking to reporters at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned the country's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table -- including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region later this week.\n\nVenezuela's defense minister called Trump's talk of a military intervention an act of \"craziness\" and \"supreme extremism.\"\n\nGen. Vladimir Padrino, a close ally of Maduro, said, \"With this extremist elite that's in charge in the U.S., who knows what will happen to the world?\"\n\nThe White House later released a statement saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela -- the third-largest supplier to the U.S. -- would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly-expanded Panama canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\n\"The Vice President's trip will highlight the divide between the past and present of Latin America,\" said Jarrod Agen, a Pence spokesman, in a statement sent before Trump's comments. \"Venezuela represents the past, with the failed path of tyranny and oppression, but Colombia, Argentina, Chile and Panama represent the future of freedom, opportunity and prosperity.\"\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\n\"You've seen Maduro have some lame attempts to try to do that already,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last Saturday on MSNBC.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" he said.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug the accusations off as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nIn eastern Caracas, the center of months of deadly anti-government protests, residents reacted with a mix of disbelief and frustration with Trump's remarks, which they fear will embolden the weakened Maduro and distract attention from his abuses.\n\n\"Of course we don't support violence, but look at all the violence we're already suffering,\" said Irali Medina, an office administrator, pointing to the spot where a university student was killed recently by a tear gas canister fired by national guardsmen controlling protesters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defense Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n__\n\nGoodman reported from Caracas, Venezuela. Associated Press writer Lolita C. Baldor in Washington contributed to this report.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-11T22:57:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"uri": "denverpost.com", "title": "The Denver Post", "id": "138"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:08:00", "url": "http://www.denverpost.com/2017/08/11/donald-trump-venezuela-military-action/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8746101", "image": "http://www.denverpost.com/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/ap17223802670417.jpg?w=640", "date": "2017-08-11", "time": "22:57:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

President Donald Trump, who included a military option as a possible action during his remarks about that nation's current turmoil.\n\nTrump's statement \"aims to drag Latin America and the Caribbean into a conflict that would permanently alter stability, peace and security in our region,\" Venezuelan Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza said, reading a statement from President Nicolas Maduro.\n\nArreaza accused Trump of \"warmongering\" and said Trump's comments represented \"the United States' systematic aggression against Venezuela.\"\n\nTrump said Friday that a military option against Venezuela was on the table, describing the situation there as a \"dangerous mess.\"\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option, if necessary,\" Trump told reporters at his golf resort in New Jersey.\n\nTrump said a military option was \"certainly something that we could pursue.\" He said the people in Venezuela were \"suffering and they are dying.\"\n\n\"We have troops all over the world in places that are very far away. Venezuela is not very far away,\" he said.\n\nTalks with Tillerson, Haley\n\nTrump said the crisis in Venezuela was one of the topics discussed during talks Friday in New Jersey with his secretary of state, Rex Tillerson, and U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley.\n\nAlso Friday, the White House said Venezuela's Maduro had requested a phone call with Trump.\n\n\"President Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country,\" a White House statement said.\n\nThe statement added that since the start of his administration, Trump had asked that Maduro respect Venezuela's constitution. But it said Maduro had \"refused to heed this call\" and instead had chosen the \"path of dictatorship.\"\n\nVenezuela's economy has been troubled since oil prices collapsed in 2014, creating severe shortages of consumer goods, including medication, and spurring inflation to triple-digit levels.\n\nEarlier this week, the Trump administration imposed new sanctions on Venezuela, targeting members of the new all-powerful constituent assembly.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T03:40:00Z", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "source": {"uri": "globalsecurity.org", "title": "GlobalSecurity.org", "id": "5033"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:40:00", "url": "http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2017/08/mil-170812-voa03.htm", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8868532", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "03:40:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}
