of Presidents of Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Veterans group sues Pentagon for not protecting private military records of millions of troops Trump threatens Venezuela with unspecified 'military option' Video Photo Venezuela's President Nicolas Maduro is pictured between palm trees as he arrives for a session of the National Constituent Assembly at Palacio Federal Legislativo in Caracas, Venezuela August 10, 2017. REUTERS/Ueslei Marcelino By James Oliphant, Reuters Aug 11, 2017 at 10:03 pm | Print View\n\nBEDMINSTER, N.J., -- U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\n'MADURO MUST BE THRILLED'\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council. (Reporting by James Oliphant; Additional reporting by Hugh Bronstein and Girish Gupta in Caracas; Writing by Jason Lange in Washington; Editing by Andrew Hay and Mary Milliken)\n\nLike what you're reading?\n\nWe make it easy to stay connected:\n\nFollow @TwitterDev Subscribe to our email newsletters Download our free apps Your next Nation & World articles More than half a million children in Lib ... Taylor Swift testifies in groping trial: ... Inflation finally may be climbing Give us feedback Have you found an error or omission in our reporting? Tell us here.\n\nDo you have a story idea we should look into? "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "BEDMINSTER, NEW JERSEY - U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled Congress.\n\nTwo renegade officers behind the attack on the base have been captured, Venezuela's military chief said Friday. Of the 20 uniformed men in the attack, two were killed and eight were captured.\n\nAlso Friday, Peru expelled Venezuela's ambassador, the strongest action yet against Caracas from a Latin American government. Venezuela retaliated by ordering the head of the Peruvian Embassy to leave.\n\nPeru also refused to accept a diplomatic protest over its hosting foreign ministers from 17 regional nations earlier in the week who refused to recognize the new loyalist-packed special assembly that is to rewrite the constitution.\n\nTrump told reporters in an impromptu question-and-answer session, \"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option if necessary.\"\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House spurned, saying Trump will gladly speak to him when democracy is restored.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces will lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation -- a military option -- is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nThe comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. President Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela has the largest known cache of weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T05:25:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"uri": "japantimes.co.jp", "title": "The Japan Times", "id": "836"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:25:00", "url": "http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/08/12/world/politics-diplomacy-world/trump-threatens-crisis-hit-venezuela-military-option/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8747272", "image": "http://www.japantimes.co.jp/wp-content/uploads/2017/08/f-venez-a-20170813.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "05:25:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 4, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro addresses the all-powerful pro-Maduro assembly which has been placed over the National Assembly and tasked with rewriting the constitution, in Caracas on Friday.(AFP)\n\nUS President Donald Trump on Friday said he was considering military options as a response to the escalating crisis in Venezuela, describing the situation there as a \"very dangerous mess.\"\n\nVenezuela President Nicolas Maduro has been under intense criticism around the world for installing a new all-powerful assembly that supersedes the Venezuelan congress and is packed with Maduro loyalists.\n\nWashington has slapped sanctions on Maduro and some of his allies, and branded him a \"dictator\" over his attempts to crush his country's opposition. Venezuela has in turn accused America of \"imperialist aggression.\"\n\nBut Friday's latest comments were the first sign that Trump may be mulling military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in New Jersey. \"We have troops all over the world in places that are very far away. Venezuela is not very far away and the people are suffering and they're dying.\"\n\nTrump said Venezuela's political crisis was among the topics discussed at the talks he hosted in New Jersey on Friday with secretary of state Rex Tillerson and UN ambassador Nikki Haley.\n\n\"Venezuela is a mess. It is very dangerous mess and a very sad situation,\" Trump said.\n\nThe White House, meanwhile, said Trump will agree to speak to Venezuela's leader \"as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\" It said Maduro requested on Friday a phone call with Trump.\n\n\"The United States stands with the people of Venezuela in the face of their continued repression by the Maduro regime. President Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country,\" the White House said in a statement.\n\nIf any US military contingency planning is under way, it must be in its early stages. A spokesman for the department of defense, Eric Pahon, refused to elaborate on Trump's comments, adding: \"As of right now, the Pentagon has received no orders.\"\n\nAnd the military command responsible for US operations in Latin America, Southern Command, said: \"The military conducts contingency planning for a variety of situations.\n\n\"If called upon, we are prepared to support whole-of-government efforts to protect our national interest and safeguard US citizens. US Southern Command has not received an order.\"\n\nQuash dissent\n\nTrump's warning came two days after his administration imposed new sanctions on Venezuela, targeting members of a loyalist assembly installed last week to bolster what Washington calls Maduro's \"dictatorship\".\n\nThe Venezuelan government responded to the sanctions -- which already targeted Maduro himself -- by saying the US was \"making a fool of itself in front of the world.\"\n\nOn Thursday, Maduro declared that Venezuela's new Constituent Assembly holds supreme power over all branches of government, even over his position, and that its work -- ostensibly to rewrite the constitution -- would return \"peace\" to the country.\n\nBut the United States and major Latin American nations allege that Maduro is using the body as a tool to quash dissent, by clamping down on the opposition and the legislature it controls.\n\nThe crisis has fuelled the street demonstrations that have gripped Venezuela for the past four months. Nearly 130 people have been killed in clashes between protesters and security forces.\n\nThe protests have lost steam in the past week as security forces have stepped up repression and demonstrators have grown discouraged by the opposition's failure to bring about change.\n\nBut hackers have taken up the torch. On Thursday a group calling itself The Binary Guardians claimed responsibility for a massive cyberattack that cut mobile telephone service to seven million users.\n\nOpposition to Maduro among the oil-exporting country's 30 million citizens increased during a long economic crisis that brought food shortages and hyperinflation to what was once of Latin America's wealthiest countries.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:56:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"uri": "hindustantimes.com", "title": "http://www.hindustantimes.com/", "id": "294"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:56:00", "url": "http://www.hindustantimes.com/world-news/us-mulls-military-option-on-venezuela-to-speak-to-maduro-when-democracy-restored/story-5Gg3UK4lvJeUtYXpDmy3PJ.html", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8735667", "image": "http://www.hindustantimes.com/rf/image_size_960x540/HT/p2/2017/08/12/Pictures/topshot-venezuela-crisis-maduro-constituent-assemby_9b324256-7f04-11e7-b5e3-d817f67cfdf5.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:56:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Venezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said US officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the US military was ready to support efforts to protect US citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned US invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if US forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\n'Maduro must be thrilled'\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbours to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe US military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former US president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for US officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, US Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T03:59:00Z", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "source": {"uri": "bdnews24.com", "title": "bdnews24.com", "id": "19272"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:59:00", "url": "http://bdnews24.com/world/2017/08/12/trump-threatens-venezuela-with-unspecified-military-option", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8740559", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "03:59:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

out the possibility of a military intervention in Venezuela in response to the South American nations descent into political chaos, the media reported.\n\nFile image of Nicolas Maduro. AFP\n\nSpeaking to reporters on Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump deplored Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table, including a potential military intervention, reports The Washington Post.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump said.\n\n\"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\n\n\"This is our neighbour. You know, we are all over the world and we have troops all over the world in places that are very, very far away. Venezuela is not very far away and the people are suffering, and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option if necessary,\" the President added.\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped sanctions on Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro after a 30 July vote that allowed him to replace the opposition-held National Assembly with a new 545-member Constituent Assembly (ANC) filled with his supporters escalating fears of turning the country into dictatorship, reports CNN.\n\nTrump's comments came after a meeting at his golf club with US Ambassador to the UN Nikki Haley and Secretary of State Rex Tillerson.\n\nIn response, Venezuela's Defence Minister Gen. Vladimir Padrino called Trump's talk of a military intervention an act of \"craziness\" and \"supreme extremism\", The Washington Post reported.\n\nPadrino, a close ally of Maduro, said: \"With this extremist elite that's in charge in the US, who knows what will happen to the world?\"\n\nMeanwhile, the White House on Friday night issued a statement saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump.\n\nThe statement said: \"The US stands with the people of Venezuela in the face of their continued oppression by the Maduro regime.\n\n\"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nVenezuela has been marred in a deepening economic crisis and political stalemate.\n\nSince Maduro announced the formation of the ANC in April, violent nationwide protests have taken place resulting in the deaths of over 100 people.\n\nPublished Date: Aug 12, 2017 09:13 am | Updated Date: Aug 12, 2017 09:14 am\n\nTags :## {"eng": "James Oliphant"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/James_Oliphant", "score": 4, "id": "505572", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of Presidents of Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "(Adds senator's reaction)\n\nBy James Oliphant\n\nBEDMINSTER, N.J., Aug 11 (Reuters) - U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\n'MADURO MUST BE THRILLED'\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council. (Reporting by James Oliphant; Additional reporting by Hugh Bronstein and Girish Gupta in Caracas; Writing by Jason Lange in Washington; Editing by Andrew Hay and Mary Milliken)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 70, "textStart": 64}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:28:00Z", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "title": "The Times of India", "id": "1185"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:28:00", "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/trump-threatens-venezuela-with-unspecified-military-option/articleshow/60029569.cms", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8733750", "image": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/photo/msid-47529300/47529300.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:28:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nNicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.Senator Ben Sasse\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.\n\n(Reporting by James Oliphant; Additional reporting by Hugh Bronstein and Girish Gupta in Caracas; Writing by Jason Lange in Washington; Editing by Andrew Hay and Mary Milliken)", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T13:23:00Z", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "source": {"uri": "huffingtonpost.ca", "title": "The Huffington Post Canada", "id": "355"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "14:09:00", "url": "http://www.huffingtonpost.ca/2017/08/12/donald-trump-hints-at-military-option-for-venezuela_a_23075497/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8802852", "image": "https://o.aolcdn.com/images/dims3/GLOB/crop/3500x1842+0+257/resize/1200x630!/format/jpg/quality/85/http%3A%2F%2Fo.aolcdn.com%2Fhss%2Fstorage%2Fmidas%2Fe3ac8fd19956b99814325fa3cb55b5ff%2F205561526%2FRTS1BFMR.jpeg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "13:23:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"302942", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Nicol\u00e1s Maduro"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nicol\u00e1s_Maduro", "score": 4, "id": "304337", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Latin America"}, "type": "loc", "score": 5, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Latin_America", "id": "304656"}, {"label": {"eng": "Mike Pence"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mike_Pence", "score": 3, "id": "304965", "type": "person"}, {"label": {"eng": "Petroleum"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petroleum", "score": 3, "id": "305421", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Panama Canal"}, "type": "loc", "score": 2, "location": null, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Panama_Canal", "id": "336919"}, {"label": {"eng": "Bolivarian Intelligence Service"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bolivarian_Intelligence_Service", "score": 3, "id": "364132", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "H. R. McMaster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._R._McMaster", "score": 2, "id": "917917", "type": "person"}], "body": "WASHINGTON (AP) -- President Donald Trump said Friday that he wouldn't rule out military action against Venezuela in response to the country's descent into political chaos following President Nicolas Maduro's power grab.\n\nSpeaking to reporters at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned the country's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table -- including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region later this week.\n\nVenezuela's defense minister called Trump's talk of a military intervention an act of \"craziness\" and \"supreme extremism.\"\n\nGen. Vladimir Padrino, a close ally of Maduro, said, \"With this extremist elite that's in charge in the U.S., who knows what will happen to the world?\"\n\nThe White House later released a statement saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela -- the third-largest supplier to the U.S. -- would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly-expanded Panama canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\n\"The Vice President's trip will highlight the divide between the past and present of Latin America,\" said Jarrod Agen, a Pence spokesman, in a statement sent before Trump's comments. \"Venezuela represents the past, with the failed path of tyranny and oppression, but Colombia, Argentina, Chile and Panama represent the future of freedom, opportunity and prosperity.\"\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\n\"You've seen Maduro have some lame attempts to try to do that already,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last Saturday on MSNBC.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" he said.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug the accusations off as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nIn eastern Caracas, the center of months of deadly anti-government protests, residents reacted with a mix of disbelief and frustration with Trump's remarks, which they fear will embolden the weakened Maduro and distract attention from his abuses.\n\n\"Of course we don't support violence, but look at all the violence we're already suffering,\" said Irali Medina, an office administrator, pointing to the spot where a university student was killed recently by a tear gas canister fired by national guardsmen controlling protesters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defense Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:13:00Z", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "source": {"uri": "timesfreepress.com", "title": "timesfreepress.com", "id": "3418"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "09:50:00", "url": "http://www.timesfreepress.com/news/breakingnews/story/2017/aug/11/trump-says-he-wont-rule-out-military-response-venezuela/443177/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8773631", "image": "http://media-cdn.timesfreepress.com/img/photos/2017/08/11/ap172238026704178234321544_t1070_h53f6d51cba2b742efdbf5f0d9c3dfafe75b70c63.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:13:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

[{"label": {"eng": "Haiti"}, "type": "loc", "score": 2, "location": {"label": {"eng": "Haiti"}, "type": "country"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Haiti", "id": "98"}, {"label": {"eng": "North "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 2, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "BEDMINSTER, N.J., (Reuters) - U.S. President Donald Trump today threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation in Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis.\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters.\n\nMore than 120 people have been killed in Venezuela and thousands arrested in over four months of unrest. The government in Caracas did not immediately respond to a request for comment on Trump's threat.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbours to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's comments could be an asset to Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. suffering, and they're dying. We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option if necessary.\"\n\nOn July 31, Maduro pushed for a vote to redraft the Venezuelan constitution via a National Constituent Assembly, an election that the Trump administration has characterized as a sham meant to turn Maduro into a dictator.\n\nVenezuela has been rocked by street protests over the move. More than 120 people have been killed and thousands arrested in over four months of unrest. The US Treasury Department last week imposed sanctions on Maduro.\n\nAsked the military option would be a US-led effort, Trump did not elaborate but said \"We don't talk about it. But a military operation, a military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nThe US military says it has not received any orders for Venezuela. There are a small number of US military personnel in Venezuela, primarily Marines guards at the Embassy.\n\nOne expert called Trump's threat of military action \"totally reckless\" and a bluff.\n\n\"We know for a fact that the US is not willing to invade Venezuela,\" Juan Carlos Hidalgo, Latin America policy analyst at the Cato Institute's Center for Global Liberty and Prosperity, said in a phone interview with NBC News.\n\nHidalgo also said Trump's comments play into Maduro's hands amid the unrest in Venezuela, because the regime \"desperately needs a scapegoat, desperately needs a foreign enemy.\"\n\nHours after Trump's remarks Friday, the White House said Maduro requested a phone call with Trump, and the White House indicated that will not happen until there are changes.\n\n\"President Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country,\" the White House office of the press secretary said in a statement.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-07-31", "textEnd": 659, "textStart": 652}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T18:10:00Z", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "source": {"uri": "financialtribune.com", "title": "Financial Tribune", "id": "18916"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:54:00", "url": "https://financialtribune.com/articles/international/70207/trump-says-military-option-possible-in-venezuela", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8892904", "image": "https://financialtribune.com/sites/default/files/styles/telegram/public/field/image/17january/03_venezuela_5.jpg?itok=E4px7vbT", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "18:10:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticized Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorizing war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\n'Maduro Must Be Thrilled'\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe US military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former US president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for US officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. "Man-portable air-defense systems"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man-portable_air-defense_systems", "score": 1, "id": "540414", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of Presidents of Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "President Donald Trump speaks to reporters in Bedminster, New Jersey on August 11, 2017. (REUTERS/Jonathan Ernst)\n\nPresident Donald Trump indicated that he will not rule out military intervention as an option to address growing instability in Venezuela.\n\nVenezuela slid toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new socialist legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump said.\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's socialist leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuela was one of the wealthiest countries in South America before Hugo Chavez instituted socialist reforms that devastated the country's economy. Maduro took over from Chavez in 2013 and continued his policies with the country sliding into mass poverty and widespread hunger.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 87, "textStart": 72}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T12:51:00Z", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "source": {"uri": "theepochtimes.com", "title": "The Epoch Times", "id": "119"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "12:51:00", "url": "http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/2280172-as-venezuelas-socialist-regime-crumbles-trump-floats-military-option/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8793556", "image": "http://www.theepochtimes.com/n3/eet-content/uploads/2017/08/12/2017-08-12T001713Z_1_LYNXMPED7B006_RTROPTP_3_USA-TRUMP.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "12:51:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "(Adds defense minister's comment, White House statement on call request)\n\nBy James Oliphant\n\nBEDMINSTER, N.J., Aug 11 (Reuters) - U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\n'MADURO MUST BE THRILLED'\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council. (Reporting by James Oliphant; Additional reporting by Hugh Bronstein and Girish Gupta in Caracas; Writing by Jason Lange in Washington; Editing by Andrew Hay and Mary Milliken)\n\nGet latest news & live updates on the go on your pc with News App. Download The Times of India news app for your device.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 117, "textStart": 111}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:13:00Z", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "source": {"uri": "timesofindia.indiatimes.com", "title": "The Times of India", "id": "1185"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:13:00", "url": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/international-business/trump-threatens-venezuela-with-unspecified-military-option/articleshow/60029448.cms", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8732756", "image": "http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/photo/msid-47529300/47529300.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:13:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

"wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of Presidents of Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Kale power: Water for crops gives women in Kenya's drylands a voice\n\n(Adds defense minister's comment, White House statement on call request)\n\nBy James Oliphant\n\nBEDMINSTER, N.J., Aug 11 (Reuters) - U.S. President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defense Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said U.S. officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the U.S. military was ready to support efforts to protect U.S. citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned U.S. invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if U.S. forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbors to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nThe U.S. military has not directly intervened in the region since a 1994-1995 operation that aimed to remove from Haiti a military government installed after a 1991 coup.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former U.S. president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.\n\nMaduro says only continuing the socialist movement started by his predecessor, Hugo Chavez, can bring peace and prosperity to Venezuela, which is suffering from an economic collapse and widespread hunger.\n\nWashington has not placed sanctions on the OPEC member's oil industry, which supplies America with about 740,000 barrels per day of oil.\n\nVenezuela possesses a stockpile of 5,000 Russian-made MANPADS surface-to-air weapons, according to military documents reviewed by Reuters. It has the largest known cache of the weapons in Latin America, posing a concern for U.S. officials during the country's mounting turmoil.\n\nThe United Nations Security Council was briefed behind closed doors on Venezuela in May at the request of the United States. At the time, U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley said Washington was just trying to raise awareness of the situation and was not seeking any action by the 15-member Security Council. (Reporting by James Oliphant; Additional reporting by Hugh Bronstein and Girish Gupta in Caracas; Writing by Jason Lange in Washington; Editing by Andrew Hay and Mary Milliken)", "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2017-08-11", "textEnd": 186, "textStart": 180}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T02:19:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"uri": "news.trust.org", "title": "news.trust.org", "id": "244"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "02:19:00", "url": "http://news.trust.org/item/20170811225813-n2uy9/", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8733181", "image": "https://d2sh4fq2xsdeg9.cloudfront.net/contentAsset/image/5cb59fc1-545f-404e-a156-7aaf83c12f35/image/byInode/1/filter/Resize,Jpeg/jpeg_q/70/resize_w/1400", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "02:19:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

Instead Maduro has chosen the path of dictatorship.\"\n\nVenezuela's Defense Minister is calling President Donald Trump's talk of a military intervention an act of \"craziness\" and \"supreme extremism.\"\n\nGen. Vladimir Padrino says, \"With this extremist elite that's in charge in the U.S., who knows what will happen to the world?\" Padrino is a close ally of President Nicolas Maduro.\n\nHis remarks are the first by a high-level Venezuelan official and come ahead of an expected statement by Maduro's government.\n\nVice President Mike Pence is heading to Latin America Sunday amid deepening alarm over Venezuela's descent into political chaos and threats of a military response by President Donald Trump.\n\nPence's six-day, four-country tour will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City.\n\nThe vice president is expected to meet with each country's leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly-expanded Panama Canal.\n\nHe's also expected to share concerns about the collapse of democracy in Venezuela and discuss trade and economic relations.\n\nThe Trump administration has issued a series of sanctions against more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials, including President Nicolas Maduro.\n\nTrump said Friday that he wouldn't rule out a \"military option\" in response to the crisis.\n\nPresident Donald Trump's threat of a \"military option\" in Venezuela seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser.\n\nGen. H.R. McMaster said last week he didn't want to give President Nicolas Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nMcMaster said in an interview that aired on MSNBC, \"You've seen Maduro have some lame attempts to try to do that already.\"\n\nMcMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\nThe general said: \"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defence Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said US officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the US military was ready to support efforts to protect US citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned US invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if US forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticised Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorising war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbours to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former US president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. 2, "id": "498474", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "List of Presidents of Venezuela"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 3, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "US President Donald Trump on Friday threatened military intervention in Venezuela, a surprise escalation of Washington's response to Venezuela's political crisis that Caracas disparaged as \"craziness.\"\n\nVenezuela has appeared to slide toward a more volatile stage of unrest in recent days, with anti-government forces looting weapons from a military base after a new legislative body usurped the authority of the opposition-controlled congress.\n\n\"The people are suffering and they are dying. We have many options for Venezuela including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters in an impromptu question and answer session.\n\nThe comments appeared to shock Caracas, with Venezuela's Defence Minister Vladimir Padrino calling the threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\nThe White House said Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro requested a phone call with Trump on Friday, which the White House appeared to spurn, saying in a statement that Trump would gladly speak to Venezuela's leader when democracy was restored in that country.\n\nVenezuelan authorities have long said US officials were planning an invasion. A former military general told Reuters earlier this year that some anti-aircraft missiles had been placed along the country's coast for precisely that eventuality.\n\nIn Washington, the Pentagon said the US military was ready to support efforts to protect US citizens and America's national interests, but that insinuations by Caracas of a planned US invasion were \"baseless.\"\n\nTrump's suggestion of possible military action came in a week when he has repeatedly threatened a military response if North Korea threatens the United States or its allies.\n\nAsked if US forces would lead an operation in Venezuela, Trump declined to provide details. \"We don't talk about it but a military operation - a military option - is certainly something that we could pursue,\" he said.\n\nSenator Ben Sasse of Nebraska, a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, criticised Trump's new stance.\n\n\"Congress obviously isn't authorising war in Venezuela,\" he said in a statement. \"Nicolas Maduro is a horrible human being, but Congress doesn't vote to spill Nebraskans' blood based on who the Executive lashes out at today.\"\n\nThe president's comments conjured up memories of gunboat diplomacy in Latin America during the 20th century, when the United States regarded its \"backyard\" neighbours to the south as underlings who it could easily intimidate through conspicuous displays of military power.\n\nTrump's more aggressive discourse could be an asset to Maduro by boosting his credibility as a national defender.\n\n\"Maduro must be thrilled right now,\" said Mark Feierstein, who was a senior aide on Venezuela matters to former US president Barack Obama. \"It's hard to imagine a more damaging thing for Trump to say.\"\n\nThe United States sanctioned Maduro and other Venezuelan officials in July after Maduro established a constituent assembly run by his Socialist Party loyalists and cracked down on opposition figures. The assembly's election drew international condemnation and critics have said it removed any remaining checks on Maduro's power.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T01:50:00Z", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "source": {"uri": "sbs.com.au", "title": "Special Broadcasting Service Corporation (SBS)", "id": "793"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "05:21:00", "url": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/article/2017/08/12/venezuela-says-trumps-threat-military-intervention-craziness", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8747045", "image": "http://www.sbs.com.au/news/sites/sbs.com.au.news/files/styles/full/public/20170812001314213428-original.jpg?itok=36xBspQJ", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "01:50:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-12"}

McMaster"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H._R._McMaster", "score": 2, "id": "917917", "type": "person"}], "body": "Speaking to reporters Friday at his Bedminster, New Jersey, golf club, Trump bemoaned Venezuela's growing humanitarian crisis and declared that all options remain on the table -- including a potential military intervention.\n\n\"We have many options for Venezuela and by the way, I'm not going to rule out a military option,\" Trump volunteered, adding, \"A military operation and military option is certainly something that we could pursue.\"\n\nTrump's comment mark a serious escalation in rhetoric for the U.S., which has up until now stressed a regional approach that encourages Latin American allies to escalate pressure on the Maduro regime. Hours before Trump's comments, a senior administration official speaking on condition of anonymity stressed that approach while briefing reporters on Vice President Mike Pence's upcoming trip to the region.\n\nVenezuela's government responded Saturday in a statement read by Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza that called Trump's talk of a potential military option an act of belligerence and a threat to Latin America's stability.\n\nThe White House released a statement Friday evening saying it had rejected a request from Maduro to speak by phone with Trump. The statement said, \"Trump will gladly speak with the leader of Venezuela as soon as democracy is restored in that country.\"\n\nThe Trump administration has slapped a series of sanctions against Maduro and more than two dozen current and former Venezuelan officials in response to a crackdown on opposition leaders and the recent election of a constitutional assembly charged with rewriting the country's constitution.\n\nBut even as the list of targeted individuals has grown longer, promised economic sanctions have yet to materialize amid an outcry by U.S. oil companies over the likelihood that a potential ban on petroleum imports from Venezuela -- the third-largest supplier to the U.S. -- would hurt U.S. jobs and drive up gas costs.\n\nTrump's comments are sure to focus new attention on Pence's upcoming six-day tour of the region, which will include stops in Cartagena, Colombia; Buenos Aires, Argentina; Santiago, Chile; and Panama City. Pence is set to arrive in Colombia on Sunday and is expected to meet with each of the countries' leaders, deliver a major speech on U.S.-Latin American relations and tour the newly expanded Panama Canal.\n\nThe trip was already sure to be dominated by discussion of Venezuela, with Pence expected to call on the leaders to continue to pressure the Maduro government and encourage others in the region to do the same.\n\nBut Trump's comments are likely to upend the conversations, with leaders potentially pressing Pence for reassurance that Trump won't go through with his military threat.\n\nTrump's threat of military intervention in Venezuela also seems to contradict the advice of his top national security adviser. Citing the resentment stirred in Latin America by the long U.S. history of military interventions in the region, General H.R. McMaster said he didn't want to give Maduro any ammunition to blame the \"Yankees\" for the \"tragedy\" that has befallen the oil-rich nation.\n\nRather than send in the Marines, McMaster said it was important for the U.S. and its neighbors to speak with a single voice in defense of Venezuela's democracy.\n\n\"It's important for us to place responsibility for this catastrophe on Maduro's shoulders. He is the one who has caused it, and he's the one who's perpetuating it,\" McMaster said in an interview that aired last weekend on MSNBC.\n\nAlmost since Maduro took office in 2013, he has been warning of U.S. military designs on Venezuela, home to the world's largest oil reserves.\n\nBut most Venezuelans tended to shrug off the accusations as diversionary tactics of an unpopular leader. One website even emerged to keep track of the multiple conspiracy theories spread on state media and Maduro's frequent harangues against Washington.\n\nBut Trump's comments that he won't rule out a \"military option\" in Venezuela may yet validate those claims in the eyes of some government supporters.\n\nAt the Pentagon, spokesman Mark Wright said the Defense Department continuously conducts contingency planning for possible military actions all around the world. \"Our job is to be prepared and be able to offer those options to the president,\" he said.\n\nStill, a senior U.S. official said the Pentagon is unaware of any coming military action in Venezuela. The official was not authorized to discuss the matter publicly so spoke on condition of anonymity.\n\n__\n\nGoodman reported from Caracas, Venezuela. Associated Press writer Lolita C.
