"http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Venezuelan_people", "score": 3, "id": "305808", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Socialism"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialism", "score": 3, "id": "305971", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "International relations"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/International_relations", "score": 2, "id": "308761", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Slavery"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slavery", "score": 3, "id": "309898", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Columbia University"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Columbia_University", "score": 2, "id": "321236", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "United States National Security Council"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_National_Security_Council", "score": 3, "id": "333388", "type": "org"}, {"label": {"eng": "Psychological warfare"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Psychological_warfare", "score": 3, "id": "369390", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Man-portable air-defense systems"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Man-portable_air-defense_systems", "score": 2, "id": "540414", "type": "wiki"}, {"label": {"eng": "Chavism"}, "uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chavism", "score": 4, "id": "1281485", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "\"We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option if necessary,\" Trump told reporters at his New Jersey golf club.\n\n\"We are all over the world and we have troops all over the world in places that are very, very far away,\" Trump said. \"Venezuela is not very far away and people are suffering and dying.\"\n\nIt was a restatement of a White House statement last July 18, where military options were implicitly suggested in these remarks here:\n\nOn Tuesday a senior White House official said that \"all options are on the table\" if Venezuela goes ahead with the vote.\n\n\"The president is very concerned about the well being of the Venezuelan people, the incredible erosion of democracy right before our eyes,\" the official said.\n\n\"And he has instructed us to do everything we can to support democracy there.\"\n\nSo that's two warnings issued to the Chavista regime. Venezuela's socialists have obviously ignored the first one in that they went through with their phony July 30 referendum to strip Venezuela's opposition legislature of any power and replace it with a handpicked Chavista super-legislature, known as the National Constituent Assembly, with the \"right\" to rewrite the constitution. The opposition, knowing that the votes had already been pre-counted in Havana, refused to participate in the farce. Nobody willingly votes himself into Cuba-style communist slavery.\n\nNow the warning comes from Trump himself, and it's far more direct and explicit.\n\nIn my piece here, I concluded that the White House warning about military options was probably psychological warfare, something to scare the Chavistas into going straight. Now that they have shown themselves impervious to threats, as well as hard sanctions, the U.S. may be inching closer to the real thing.\n\nWhy do I think that?\n\nNumber one, because of the Pentagon's cryptic response.\n\n\"I refer you to the White House \u200eto clarify the president's comments,\" Pentagon spokesman Eric Pahon said. \"The Pentagon has received no orders in regard to Venezuela.\"\n\n\"The military conducts contingency planning for a variety of situations,\" Pahon continued. \"If called upon, we are prepared to support whole-of-government efforts to protect our national interest and safeguard U.S. citizens.\"\n\nIt goes without saying that the Pentagon is hardly going to announce an invasion before it happens, so naturally, it would say it has no orders. Number two, those orders would probably be proposed by the National Security Council for the president's approval, not the Pentagon alone.\n\nIt's that second half of the statement that is worth looking at, specifically the last, superfluous sentence.\n\nIf called upon, we are prepared to support whole-of-government efforts to protect our national interest and safeguard U.S. citizens.\n\nSince Trump's first July 18 warning, a lot of stuff has happened since then - not just the July 30 referendum, but also the mysterious raid on an elite, high-security military installation near Valencia, where, apparently, opponents of the regime successfully breached the compound and made off with a large number of weapons, presumably for a rebellion or civil war.\n\nRecall that Russia has supplied Venezuela with thousands of rifles but also 5,000 MANPADS, or hand-held surface-to-air missiles. If the raiders were not apparent rebels, but perhaps drug dealers, Mexican cartel members, ISIS, or FARC terrorists, the picture of the raid looks very different. It shows a country whose military is falling apart, and its disintegration is running to the benefit of the region's worst non-state actors. In that case, a military invasion might be easily justified, given the direct threat to U.S. national security. It would square with the Pentagon's last remark.\n\nMeanwhile, the foreign policy establishment is up in arms about the remarks, saying President Trump is losing friends in the region.\n\nHis temperate approach over the past few weeks has helped build a regional coalition that was very vocal in denouncing and putting pressure on the Venezuelan government,\" said Christopher Sabatini, a Columbia University international relations and policy lecturer. \"By sounding off now, he has really made it much more difficult for Latin American governments to adhere to what is seen as the U.S. position.\n\nHe's also, of course, tapped - I think unwittingly - into this deep, deep, legitimate worry and fear of U.S. intervention. This doesn't play well in Latin America.\"\n\nOn that, I suspect that the call is wrong. The analysts leveling the criticisms (and I know and have great respect for Chris Sabatini) are operating on old information, and I argue that the times have since changed.\n\nThe indicator for that is Vice President Pence's upcoming trip to Latin America, which will see him paying visits to four strategically important countries to the Venezuelan situation: Panama, Colombia, Argentina, and Chile. Panama and Colombia are already experiencing human waves of Venezuelan refugees spilling over into their countries (as is Brazil), and Argentina and Chile are important nations to get on our side. Their own histories, and in Chile's case, its leftist government, predispose them to be hostile to U.S. but usually not any other invasions. Pence's mission may be to just get Chile to stay quiet, and perhaps to get Argentina onboard. I can't see Panama or Colombia opposing a military invasion, given the problems they are facing with refugees. Times have changed, and the status quo has since shifted.\n\nCould there be an invasion while the U.S. is so tied up with North Korea and the Obama administration left the U.S. military so depleted? That would tilt the balance a bit toward wait-and-see. Leon Panetta, a former defense secretary, puts it obnoxiously toward President Trump, but he might have a point about whether the U.S. can handle another flashpoint in the wake of the North Korean crisis. There may be a military invasion of Venezuela, but from what is known so far, unless the threat is real and immediate in the wake of the weapons raid or another event, and unless it would be a real cheapie to execute, it won't happen today or tomorrow.", "extractedDates": [{"imp": true, "textEnd": 388, "amb": false, "date": "2017-07-18", "textStart": 381, "freq": 2}, {"imp": true, "textEnd": 989, "amb": false, "date": "2017-07-30", "textStart": 982, "freq": 2}], "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T13:37:00Z", "sim": 0.4627451002597809, "source": {"uri": "americanthinker.com", "title": "americanthinker.com", "id": "95"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "03:28:00", "url": "http://www.americanthinker.com/blog/2017/08/so_is_trump_serious_about_taking_out_venezuela.html", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8867169", "image": "http://www.americanthinker.com/assets/images/at-painter-og-image.png", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "13:37:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

hours since U.S. President Donald Trump said Washington is exploring \"many options regarding Venezuela, including a possible military option if necessary\", the global community has continued to condemn his comments.\n\nIn a teleSUR exclusive, the U.S. intellectual Noam Chomsky said the remarks were \"shocking and dangerous\".\n\nChomsky believes Trump maybe \"painting himself into a corner. It is worth remembering that he is probably following his usual practice of speaking to his base, and trying to ensure that he remains in the limelight, not caring much about real world consequences (except to his pocketbook and image). The best hope is that some of the generals around him, who presumably understand the consequences, will manage to control him.\"\n\nRegional powers have also come out strongly against the comments.\n\nEcuador says it \"reminds the international community that the declaration of Latin America and the Caribbean as a zone of peace implies the commitment of all nations to preserve our common territory free of threats or military interventions of any kind. In this context, it expresses its solidarity with the Bolivarian Republic of Venezuela and rejects any threat of possible military intrusion into its territory. Ecuador reiterates the call for dialogue as the only way to solve the situation of the brother Venezuelan people.\n\nThe Peruvian government issued a statement saying it \"rejects any threat or use of force not authorized by the United Nations Security Council.\"\n\n[COMUNICADO OFICIAL] Per\u00fa rechaza cualquier amenaza al uso de la fuerza en #Venezuela https://t.co/m91Iwp8xzo the issue.\n\nThe Colombian government said it rejects military options and the use of force against its neighbor and insists \"It is necessary to respect the Charter of the United Nations and international law, and the sovereignty of Venezuela through peaceful solutions.\"\n\nTrump's threats were renounced by Mexico, echoing Bogota's assertion that a solution would not be found through \"internal or external military actions.\"\n\nBrazilian Foreign Minister Aloysio Nunes announced that his nation does not support military intervention in Venezuela.\n\n\"The time for the big stick has passed,\" he said. \"Our path is that of diplomacy, politics and negotiation.\"\n\nThe Southern Common Market, Mercosur, also issued a statement alluding to Trump's threat.\n\n\"Mercosur considers that the only acceptable instruments for the promotion of democracy are dialouge and diplomacy,\" the statement said.\n\n\"The repudiation of violence and any option involving the use of force is unavoidable and constitutes the fundamental basis of democratic coexistence, both internally and in international relations.\"\n\nAnd many other have been making their views clear:\n\nReiterando todos "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 2, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "HAVANA, Aug. 12 (Xinhua) -- Recent threats made by U.S. President Donald Trump about a \"possible military option\" in Venezuela constitute a \"serious aggression\" to Latin America and the Caribbean, a Cuban professor said here on Saturday.\n\nLuis Suarez, a Cuban professor on international relations, reckons this direct threat as an explicit violation of the declaration of Latin America and the Caribbean as a peace zone, signed in Havana in 2014 by all presidents of the region during the annual summit of the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States.\n\n\"Part of the essential content of the declaration is that all countries reject not only military aggression but also any threats to use force as part of the mechanism of relations between nations of the hemisphere,\" he told Xinhua.\n\nTrump said on Friday, \"We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option, if necessary.\"\n\nHis remarks came amid growing tensions between Washington and Caracas over Venezuela's controversial Constituent National Assembly (ANC) formed after an election late last month.\n\nThe United States has imposed a series of sanctions on Venezuelan individuals involved in the ANC, including Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, to support the opposition Democratic Unity Roundtable (MUD), which boycotted the July 30 election as it claimed the ANC would only consolidate the power of the ruling party.\n\nSuarez said the new escalation of Trump's remarks is a \"direct aggression\" to the peace and independence of Latin America and the Caribbean.\n\nAccording to Suarez, the U.S. military option in Venezuela could be carried out under the pretext of a \"humanitarian intervention.\"\n\n\"What Trump said somehow opens up all the options that have been assessed by Washington regarding Venezuela,\" Suarez said.\n\nSuarez said Trump's words are part of a \"plan\" carried out in the last few months to topple the Venezuelan leader and \"implode\" the nation with severe food and medicine shortages.\n\nThe expert said Washington has been trying to \"legitimize\" its policy of aggression against Caracas in the last few weeks to justify a possible military intervention.\n\n\"This U.S. administration has a deep inclination to militarism and that simply has to be denounced,\" he said.\n\nIn this context, U.S. Vice President Mike Pence heads to four Latin American countries, Colombia, Argentina, Chile and Panama in the next few days.\n\n\"The Community of Latin American and Caribbean States.\n\n\"Part of the essential content of the declaration is that all countries reject not only military aggression but also any threats to use force as necessary.\"\n\nHis remarks came amid growing tensions between Washington and Caracas over Venezuela's controversial Constituent National Assembly (ANC) formed after an election late last "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Presidents_of_Venezuela", "score": 2, "id": "1366321", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "A Cuban professor on international relations, Luis Suarez has said that the treats made by U.S. President Donald Trump about a \"possible military option\" in Venezuela, constitutes a \"serious aggression\" to Latin America and the Caribbean.\n\nSuarez reckons this direct threat as an explicit violation of the declaration of Latin America and the Caribbean as a peace zone, signed in Havana in 2014 by all presidents of the region during the annual summit of the Community of Latin American and Caribbean States.\n\n\"Part of the essential content of the declaration is that all countries reject not only military aggression but also any threats to use force as part of the mechanism of relations between nations of the hemisphere,\" he told Xinhua.\n\nTrump said on Friday, \"We have many options for Venezuela, including a possible military option, if necessary.\"\n\nHis remarks came amid growing tensions between Washington and Caracas over Venezuela's controversial Constituent National Assembly (ANC) formed after an election late last month.\n\nThe U.S. has imposed a series of sanctions on Venezuelan individuals involved in the ANC, including Venezuelan President Nicolas Maduro, to support the opposition Democratic Unity Roundtable (MUD).\n\nThe MUD boycotted the July 30 election as it claimed the ANC would only consolidate the power of the ruling party.\n\nSuarez said the new escalation of Trump's remarks is a \"direct aggression\" to the peace and independence of Latin America and the Caribbean.\n\nAccording to Suarez, the U.S. military option in Venezuela could be carried out under the pretext of a \"humanitarian intervention.\"\n\n\"What Trump said somehow opens up all the options that have been assessed by Washington regarding Venezuela,\" Suarez said.\n\nSuarez said Trump's words are part of a \"plan\" carried out in the last few months to topple the Venezuelan leader and \"implode\" the nation with severe food and medicine shortages.\n\nThe expert said Washington has been trying to \"legitimise\" its policy of aggression against Caracas in the last few weeks to justify a possible military intervention.\n\n\"This U.S. administration has a deep inclination to militarism and that simply has to be denounced,\" he said.\n\nIn this context, U.S. Vice President Mike Pence heads to four Latin American countries, Colombia, Argentina, Chile and Panama in the next few days.\n\n\"The U.S. vice president specifically visits four of the governments that have been very active throughout this operation of aggression and pressure against Venezuela,\" said Suarez.", "extractedDates": [{"amb": Trump aims to drag Latin America and the Caribbean into a conflict that would permanently alter stability, peace and security in our region,\" Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza told a news conference, control of its oil reserves, the biggest in the world.\n\n- 'Vile threats' -\n\nTrump had said the military option was among a range of scenarios he was considering to fix the \"very dangerous mess\" democratic rule.\"\n\nPeru on Friday ordered Venezuela's ambassador to leave, with Caracas reacting by ordering out Lima's envoy.\n\nBut not all of Latin America is ranged against Maduro. "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Delcy_Rodr\u00edguez", "score": 2, "id": "1288788", "type": "wiki"}], "body": "Stability across Latin America is in jeopardy from President Donald Trump's \"reckless threat\" to consider military action against Venezuela, Caracas said on Saturday, after its military vowed to stand up to the US leader's \"craziness.\"\n\nThe warning from Trump on Friday that his administration was mulling many options, \"including a possible military option if necessary,\" struck the government of Venezuela's beleaguered leftist president, Nicolas Maduro, like a thunderbolt.\n\nThe leadership of the crisis-wracked nation -- Latin America's biggest oil producer and an ally to Russia and Cuba -- suddenly found itself going from battling dissent, protests and growing international isolation to contemplating US military action last seen in the region in 1989, when American troops invaded Panama to topple its president, Manuel Noriega.\n\n\"The reckless threat by President Donald Trump aims to drag Latin America and the Caribbean into a conflict that would permanently alter stability, peace and security in our region,\" Foreign Minister Jorge Arreaza told a news conference, reading a statement in Maduro's name.\n\nThe menace, however, also gave Maduro's regime an unexpected opportunity to substantiate its daily refrain that it is a victim of a Washington plot to grab control of its oil reserves, the biggest in the world.\n\nThe military, current and retired members of which control a third of the government, leapt on the threat to say it was the nation's only bulwark against the \"imperialist aggression.\"\n\nGeneral Vladimir Padrino, Venezuela's defense minister and commander of its armed forces, on Friday called Trump's threat \"an act of craziness.\"\n\n\"I am certain that we will all be in the first ranks defending the interests and sovereignty of our beloved Venezuela,\" he said.\n\n- 'Vile threats' -\n\nTrump had said the military option was among a range of scenarios he was considering to fix the \"very dangerous mess\" in Venezuela.\n\nHe has already had his government impose sanctions on Maduro -- an extremely rare step against a head of state -- and two dozen of his officials.\n\nThey were for perceived moves towards a \"dictatorship\" in Venezuela, especially through Maduro's establishment this month of a new, all-powerful assembly filled with loyalists that has powers to override the country's legislature, controlled by the opposition.\n\nThe head of that new Constituent Assembly, Delcy Rodriguez, said on Twitter: \"We reject the cowardly, insolent and vile threats against the sacred sovereignty of Venezuela.\"\n\nThe assembly was elected two weeks ago in a vote marred by allegations of fraud, an opposition boycott and violent protests and repression by security forces that brought the death toll in four months of unrest to more than 125.\n\nSince starting work, the assembly -- ostensibly tasked with rewriting the constitution -- has fired Venezuela's attorney general who had become a major critic of Maduro, and stepped up measures to quash opposition politicians.\n\nThe supreme court, which has also shown itself consistently loyal to Maduro, stripped two opposition mayors of the right to public office and ordered them to jail, bringing to 23 the number targeted by legal action.\n\n- Regional unease -\n\nThe developments have prompted major Latin American nations Argentina, Brazil, Chile, Mexico and Peru to slam Maduro's government for \"breaking democratic rule.\"\n\nPeru on Friday ordered Venezuela's ambassador to leave, with Caracas reacting by ordering out Lima's envoy.\n\nBut not all of Latin America is ranged against Maduro. Venezuela can still count on support from leftist allies Cuba, Bolivia, Ecuador and Nicaragua, as well as a handful of Caribbean nations that depend on it for cheap or free oil.\n\nThe prospect of US military action in a region that has very bitter memories of multiple such interventions last century has stirred unease even among countries opposed to Venezuela.\n\nUS Vice President Mike Pence will on Sunday begin a Latin American visit -- a trip seen as coordinating action between Washington and regional powers against Venezuela.\n\nBrazil on Saturday said it and the other members of the South American trading bloc Mercosur -- from which Venezuela was suspended indefinitely days ago -- rejected the threat of force.\n\n\"The repudiation of violence and whatever option involving the use of force is resolute and constitutes a fundamental basis of democratic cohabitation, both in domestic contexts as well as in international relations,\" Brazil's foreign ministry said in a statement.", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-12T18:03:00Z", "sim": 0, "source": {"uri": "sg.news.yahoo.com", "title": "sg.news.yahoo.com", "id": "18491"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "08:41:00", "url": "https://sg.news.yahoo.com/venezuela-says-latin-america-stability-risk-reckless-trump-185612810.html", "storyUri": "eng-3356011", "id": "8891461", "image": "https://s.yimg.com/uu/api/res/1.2/.t5FC7CJfiVILEoHiw6Cjg--/aD01MTM7dz03Njg7c209MTthcHBpZD15dGFjaHlvbg--/http://media.zenfs.com/en_sg/News/AFP/9d8f45cf4c06d0bd16a39c3c350d641aaab56c20.jpg", "date": "2017-08-12", "time": "18:03:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}

Donald Trump hat mit seiner milit\u00e4rischen Drohung gegen das krisengesch\u00fcttelte Venezuela in ganz Lateinamerika Befremden ausgel\u00f6st. Verb\u00fcndete sowie Kritiker des linken Pr\u00e4sidenten Nicol\u00e1s Maduro wiesen eine Intervention zur\u00fcck. \"Jetzt wei\u00df die Welt: Jene, die gegen Maduro sind, streben nur ein milit\u00e4risches Eingreifen des Imperiums an\", sagte Boliviens Pr\u00e4sident Evo Morales, ein enger Verb\u00fcndeter Venezuelas.\n\nLauter Milliard\u00e4re: Geldscheine w\u00e4hrend der Hyperinflation 1923 Mit Hammer und Zirkel: Die bis 1989 g\u00fcltigen DDR-Geldscheine Geheime Scheine: Diese DM-Banknoten hatten wir nie im Geldbeutel\n\nMit Kolumbien, Mexiko und Peru verurteilten aber auch die sch\u00e4rfsten Kritiker von Maduros sozialistischer Regierung das S\u00e4belrasseln von Trump. \"Wir lehnen milit\u00e4rische Mittel und Gewaltanwendung im internationalen System ab\", teilte das kolumbianische Au\u00dfenministerium am Wochenende mit.\n\nAngesichts der Krise in Venezuela hatte Trump \u00fcberraschend eine milit\u00e4rische Option ins Gespr\u00e4ch gebracht. \"Wir haben viele Optionen f\u00fcr Venezuela, einschlie\u00dflich einer milit\u00e4rischen, falls n\u00f6tig\", sagte er am Freitag in seinem Urlaubsdomizil in Bedminster (New Jersey). Es war nicht unmittelbar klar, was Trump damit meinte.\n\nAnzeige - Heiz\u00f6lpreisrechner AnzeigeHeiz\u00f6lpreisrechner\n\nVenezuelas Pr\u00e4sident Maduro hatte zuletzt eine Verfassungsgebende Versammlung w\u00e4hlen lassen und damit das demokratisch gew\u00e4hlte Parlament faktisch entmachtet. Oppositionelle und zahlreiche Staaten werfen ihm vor, ein autorit\u00e4res Regierungssystem zu errichten.\n\nVon milit\u00e4rischen Planspielen oder auch nur konkreteren \u00dcberlegungen in Sachen Venezuela ist seitens der US-Regierung nichts bekannt. \"Das Pentagon hat keine Befehle erhalten\", zitierten Medien einen Sprecher des Verteidigungsministeriums. Venezuelas Verteidigungsminister Vladimir Padrino sagte zu Trumps Worten: \"Das ist ein verr\u00fcckter Akt, ein Akt des Extremismus.\"\n\nKritik an Trumps Drohung kamen auch aus den eigenen Reihen. \"Der Kongress wird nat\u00fcrlich keinem Krieg in Venezuela zustimmen\", sagte der republikanische Senator und einer von Trumps sch\u00e4rfsten innerparteilichen Kritikern, Ben Sasse, dem \"Washington Examiner\".\n\nVenezuelas Regierung warf den USA nach Trumps \u00c4u\u00dferungen imperialistische Bestrebungen vor und rief die lateinamerikanischen L\u00e4nder zur Solidarit\u00e4t auf. \"Das ist eine direkte Bedrohung des Friedens, der Stabilit\u00e4t, der Unabh\u00e4ngigkeit, der regionalen Einheit, der Souver\u00e4nit\u00e4t und des Rechts auf Selbstbestimmung\", sagte Au\u00dfenminister Jorge Arreaza.\n\nAnalysten kritisierten, Trump spiele mit seiner Kriegsrhetorik der sozialistischen Regierung von Maduro in die H\u00e4nde. Der venezolanische Pr\u00e4sident warnt seit Monaten vor Interventionspl\u00e4nen der USA und beschuldigt die Opposition, gemeinsam mit Washington gegen ihn zu konspirieren. Trumps \u00c4u\u00dferungen liefern nun einen scheinbaren Beweis f\u00fcr seine Anschuldigungen.\n\nKurz zuvor hatte sich Maduro noch um ein Gespr\u00e4ch mit Trump bem\u00fcht. Allerdings erteilte ihm das Wei\u00dfe Haus eine Abfuhr. \"Pr\u00e4sident Trump wird gerne mit dem F\u00fchrer Venezuelas sprechen, sobald die Demokratie in diesem Land wiederhergestellt ist\", hie\u00df es in der Erkl\u00e4rung.\n\nF\u00fcr Maduro ist die Abweisung und Ver\u00f6ffentlichung des ungew\u00f6hnlichen Vorgangs peinlich, weil sie ihn als Bittsteller dastehen l\u00e4sst. Trotz aller Differenzen sind die USA der wichtigste Abnehmer von Erd\u00f6l, ohne die Exporte in die USA droht die Staatspleite. Nach dem derzeitigen \u00d6lpreis importieren die USA f\u00fcr rund zehn Milliarden Dollar im Jahr \u00d6l aus dem am Rande des Ruins stehenden Landes.\n\nUS-Au\u00dfenminister Rex Tillerson hatte zuletzt wiederholt betont, keine Option in Bezug auf Venezuela sei ausgeschlossen - da ging es aber eher um die Frage nach einem Importstopp f\u00fcr \u00d6l aus Venezuela. Gegen mittlerweile \u00fcber 20 Personen der F\u00fchrungselite wurden Sanktionen verh\u00e4ngt, auch gegen Maduro. M\u00f6gliche Verm\u00f6gen und Konten, auf die US-Beh\u00f6rden Zugriff haben, werden eingefroren, US-B\u00fcrgern sind Gesch\u00e4fte mit den auf der Liste stehenden Personen verboten.\n\nUS-Finanzminister Steve Mnuchin hatte betont: \"Pr\u00e4sident Maduro hat diese illegitime Verfassungsgebende Versammlung vereidigt, um seine Diktatur weiter zu festigen.\" Maduro ist erst der vierte Staatschef, der von den USA mit Finanzsanktionen belegt wurde - nach Kim Jong Un (Nordkorea), Robert Mugabe (Simbabwe) und Baschar al-Assad (Syrien).", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T13:55:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"uri": "t-online.de", "title": "T-online.de", "id": "139"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:55:00", "url": "http://www.t-online.de/finanzen/boerse/news/id_81879982/wirtschaft-latinos-weisen-trumps-militaerische-option-gegen-venezuela-zurueck.html", "storyUri": "deu-753256", "id": "8923173", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "13:55:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}], "page": 1, "totalResults": 702, "count": 1}}}

Donald Trump hat mit seiner milit\u00e4rischen Drohung gegen das krisengesch\u00fcttelte Venezuela in ganz Lateinamerika Befremden ausgel\u00f6st. Verb\u00fcndete sowie Kritiker des linken Pr\u00e4sidenten Nicol\u00e1s Maduro wiesen eine Intervention zur\u00fcck. \"Jetzt wei\u00df die Welt: Jene, die gegen Maduro sind, streben nur ein milit\u00e4risches Eingreifen des Imperiums an\", sagte Boliviens Pr\u00e4sident Evo Morales, ein enger Verb\u00fcndeter Venezuelas.\n\nLauter Milliard\u00e4re: Geldscheine w\u00e4hrend der Hyperinflation 1923 Mit Hammer und Zirkel: Die bis 1989 g\u00fcltigen DDR-Geldscheine Geheime Scheine: Diese DM-Banknoten hatten wir nie im Geldbeutel\n\nMit Kolumbien, Mexiko und Peru verurteilten aber auch die sch\u00e4rfsten Kritiker von Maduros sozialistischer Regierung das S\u00e4belrasseln von Trump. \"Wir lehnen milit\u00e4rische Mittel und Gewaltanwendung im internationalen System ab\", teilte das kolumbianische Au\u00dfenministerium am Wochenende mit.\n\nAngesichts der Krise in Venezuela hatte Trump \u00fcberraschend eine milit\u00e4rische Option ins Gespr\u00e4ch gebracht. \"Wir haben viele Optionen f\u00fcr Venezuela, einschlie\u00dflich einer milit\u00e4rischen, falls n\u00f6tig\", sagte er am Freitag in seinem Urlaubsdomizil in Bedminster (New Jersey). Es war nicht unmittelbar klar, was Trump damit meinte.\n\nAnzeige - Heiz\u00f6lpreisrechner AnzeigeHeiz\u00f6lpreisrechner\n\nVenezuelas Pr\u00e4sident Maduro hatte zuletzt eine Verfassungsgebende Versammlung w\u00e4hlen lassen und damit das demokratisch gew\u00e4hlte Parlament faktisch entmachtet. Oppositionelle und zahlreiche Staaten werfen ihm vor, ein autorit\u00e4res Regierungssystem zu errichten.\n\nVon milit\u00e4rischen Planspielen oder auch nur konkreteren \u00dcberlegungen in Sachen Venezuela ist seitens der US-Regierung nichts bekannt. \"Das Pentagon hat keine Befehle erhalten\", zitierten Medien einen Sprecher des Verteidigungsministeriums. Venezuelas Verteidigungsminister Vladimir Padrino sagte zu Trumps Worten: \"Das ist ein verr\u00fcckter Akt, ein Akt des Extremismus.\"\n\nKritik an Trumps Drohung kamen auch aus den eigenen Reihen. \"Der Kongress wird nat\u00fcrlich keinem Krieg in Venezuela zustimmen\", sagte der republikanische Senator und einer von Trumps sch\u00e4rfsten innerparteilichen Kritikern, Ben Sasse, dem \"Washington Examiner\".\n\nVenezuelas Regierung warf den USA nach Trumps \u00c4u\u00dferungen imperialistische Bestrebungen vor und rief die lateinamerikanischen L\u00e4nder zur Solidarit\u00e4t auf. \"Das ist eine direkte Bedrohung des Friedens, der Stabilit\u00e4t, der Unabh\u00e4ngigkeit, der regionalen Einheit, der Souver\u00e4nit\u00e4t und des Rechts auf Selbstbestimmung\", sagte Au\u00dfenminister Jorge Arreaza.\n\nAnalysten kritisierten, Trump spiele mit seiner Kriegsrhetorik der sozialistischen Regierung von Maduro in die H\u00e4nde. Der venezolanische Pr\u00e4sident warnt seit Monaten vor Interventionspl\u00e4nen der USA und beschuldigt die Opposition, gemeinsam mit Washington gegen ihn zu konspirieren. Trumps \u00c4u\u00dferungen liefern nun einen scheinbaren Beweis f\u00fcr seine Anschuldigungen.\n\nKurz zuvor hatte sich Maduro noch um ein Gespr\u00e4ch mit Trump bem\u00fcht. Allerdings erteilte ihm das Wei\u00dfe Haus eine Abfuhr. \"Pr\u00e4sident Trump wird gerne mit dem F\u00fchrer Venezuelas sprechen, sobald die Demokratie in diesem Land wiederhergestellt ist\", hie\u00df es in der Erkl\u00e4rung.\n\nF\u00fcr Maduro ist die Abweisung und Ver\u00f6ffentlichung des ungew\u00f6hnlichen Vorgangs peinlich, weil sie ihn als Bittsteller dastehen l\u00e4sst. Trotz aller Differenzen sind die USA der wichtigste Abnehmer von Erd\u00f6l, ohne die Exporte in die USA droht die Staatspleite. Nach dem derzeitigen \u00d6lpreis importieren die USA f\u00fcr rund zehn Milliarden Dollar im Jahr \u00d6l aus dem am Rande des Ruins stehenden Landes.\n\nUS-Au\u00dfenminister Rex Tillerson hatte zuletzt wiederholt betont, keine Option in Bezug auf Venezuela sei ausgeschlossen - da ging es aber eher um die Frage nach einem Importstopp f\u00fcr \u00d6l aus Venezuela. Gegen mittlerweile \u00fcber 20 Personen der F\u00fchrungselite wurden Sanktionen verh\u00e4ngt, auch gegen Maduro. M\u00f6gliche Verm\u00f6gen und Konten, auf die US-Beh\u00f6rden Zugriff haben, werden eingefroren, US-B\u00fcrgern sind Gesch\u00e4fte mit den auf der Liste stehenden Personen verboten.\n\nUS-Finanzminister Steve Mnuchin hatte betont: \"Pr\u00e4sident Maduro hat diese illegitime Verfassungsgebende Versammlung vereidigt, um seine Diktatur weiter zu festigen.\" Maduro ist erst der vierte Staatschef, der von den USA mit Finanzsanktionen belegt wurde - nach Kim Jong Un (Nordkorea), Robert Mugabe (Simbabwe) und Baschar al-Assad (Syrien).", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T13:55:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"uri": "t-online.de", "title": "T-online.de", "id": "139"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:55:00", "url": "http://www.t-online.de/finanzen/boerse/news/id_81879982/wirtschaft-latinos-weisen-trumps-militaerische-option-gegen-venezuela-zurueck.html", "storyUri": "deu-753256", "id": "8923173", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "13:55:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}], "page": 1, "totalResults": 702, "count": 1}}}

Donald Trump hat mit seiner milit\u00e4rischen Drohung gegen das krisengesch\u00fcttelte Venezuela in ganz Lateinamerika Befremden ausgel\u00f6st. Verb\u00fcndete sowie Kritiker des linken Pr\u00e4sidenten Nicol\u00e1s Maduro wiesen eine Intervention zur\u00fcck. \"Jetzt wei\u00df die Welt: Jene, die gegen Maduro sind, streben nur ein milit\u00e4risches Eingreifen des Imperiums an\", sagte Boliviens Pr\u00e4sident Evo Morales, ein enger Verb\u00fcndeter Venezuelas.\n\nLauter Milliard\u00e4re: Geldscheine w\u00e4hrend der Hyperinflation 1923 Mit Hammer und Zirkel: Die bis 1989 g\u00fcltigen DDR-Geldscheine Geheime Scheine: Diese DM-Banknoten hatten wir nie im Geldbeutel\n\nMit Kolumbien, Mexiko und Peru verurteilten aber auch die sch\u00e4rfsten Kritiker von Maduros sozialistischer Regierung das S\u00e4belrasseln von Trump. \"Wir lehnen milit\u00e4rische Mittel und Gewaltanwendung im internationalen System ab\", teilte das kolumbianische Au\u00dfenministerium am Wochenende mit.\n\nAngesichts der Krise in Venezuela hatte Trump \u00fcberraschend eine milit\u00e4rische Option ins Gespr\u00e4ch gebracht. \"Wir haben viele Optionen f\u00fcr Venezuela, einschlie\u00dflich einer milit\u00e4rischen, falls n\u00f6tig\", sagte er am Freitag in seinem Urlaubsdomizil in Bedminster (New Jersey). Es war nicht unmittelbar klar, was Trump damit meinte.\n\nAnzeige - Heiz\u00f6lpreisrechner AnzeigeHeiz\u00f6lpreisrechner\n\nVenezuelas Pr\u00e4sident Maduro hatte zuletzt eine Verfassungsgebende Versammlung w\u00e4hlen lassen und damit das demokratisch gew\u00e4hlte Parlament faktisch entmachtet. Oppositionelle und zahlreiche Staaten werfen ihm vor, ein autorit\u00e4res Regierungssystem zu errichten.\n\nVon milit\u00e4rischen Planspielen oder auch nur konkreteren \u00dcberlegungen in Sachen Venezuela ist seitens der US-Regierung nichts bekannt. \"Das Pentagon hat keine Befehle erhalten\", zitierten Medien einen Sprecher des Verteidigungsministeriums. Venezuelas Verteidigungsminister Vladimir Padrino sagte zu Trumps Worten: \"Das ist ein verr\u00fcckter Akt, ein Akt des Extremismus.\"\n\nKritik an Trumps Drohung kamen auch aus den eigenen Reihen. \"Der Kongress wird nat\u00fcrlich keinem Krieg in Venezuela zustimmen\", sagte der republikanische Senator und einer von Trumps sch\u00e4rfsten innerparteilichen Kritikern, Ben Sasse, dem \"Washington Examiner\".\n\nVenezuelas Regierung warf den USA nach Trumps \u00c4u\u00dferungen imperialistische Bestrebungen vor und rief die lateinamerikanischen L\u00e4nder zur Solidarit\u00e4t auf. \"Das ist eine direkte Bedrohung des Friedens, der Stabilit\u00e4t, der Unabh\u00e4ngigkeit, der regionalen Einheit, der Souver\u00e4nit\u00e4t und des Rechts auf Selbstbestimmung\", sagte Au\u00dfenminister Jorge Arreaza.\n\nAnalysten kritisierten, Trump spiele mit seiner Kriegsrhetorik der sozialistischen Regierung von Maduro in die H\u00e4nde. Der venezolanische Pr\u00e4sident warnt seit Monaten vor Interventionspl\u00e4nen der USA und beschuldigt die Opposition, gemeinsam mit Washington gegen ihn zu konspirieren. Trumps \u00c4u\u00dferungen liefern nun einen scheinbaren Beweis f\u00fcr seine Anschuldigungen.\n\nKurz zuvor hatte sich Maduro noch um ein Gespr\u00e4ch mit Trump bem\u00fcht. Allerdings erteilte ihm das Wei\u00dfe Haus eine Abfuhr. \"Pr\u00e4sident Trump wird gerne mit dem F\u00fchrer Venezuelas sprechen, sobald die Demokratie in diesem Land wiederhergestellt ist\", hie\u00df es in der Erkl\u00e4rung.\n\nF\u00fcr Maduro ist die Abweisung und Ver\u00f6ffentlichung des ungew\u00f6hnlichen Vorgangs peinlich, weil sie ihn als Bittsteller dastehen l\u00e4sst. Trotz aller Differenzen sind die USA der wichtigste Abnehmer von Erd\u00f6l, ohne die Exporte in die USA droht die Staatspleite. Nach dem derzeitigen \u00d6lpreis importieren die USA f\u00fcr rund zehn Milliarden Dollar im Jahr \u00d6l aus dem am Rande des Ruins stehenden Landes.\n\nUS-Au\u00dfenminister Rex Tillerson hatte zuletzt wiederholt betont, keine Option in Bezug auf Venezuela sei ausgeschlossen - da ging es aber eher um die Frage nach einem Importstopp f\u00fcr \u00d6l aus Venezuela. Gegen mittlerweile \u00fcber 20 Personen der F\u00fchrungselite wurden Sanktionen verh\u00e4ngt, auch gegen Maduro. M\u00f6gliche Verm\u00f6gen und Konten, auf die US-Beh\u00f6rden Zugriff haben, werden eingefroren, US-B\u00fcrgern sind Gesch\u00e4fte mit den auf der Liste stehenden Personen verboten.\n\nUS-Finanzminister Steve Mnuchin hatte betont: \"Pr\u00e4sident Maduro hat diese illegitime Verfassungsgebende Versammlung vereidigt, um seine Diktatur weiter zu festigen.\" Maduro ist erst der vierte Staatschef, der von den USA mit Finanzsanktionen belegt wurde - nach Kim Jong Un (Nordkorea), Robert Mugabe (Simbabwe) und Baschar al-Assad (Syrien).", "extractedDates": null, "isDuplicate": false, "eventUri": "eng-3356011", "details": {}, "dateTime": "2017-08-13T13:55:00Z", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "source": {"uri": "t-online.de", "title": "T-online.de", "id": "139"}, "originalArticle": null, "timeCrawl": "13:55:00", "url": "http://www.t-online.de/finanzen/boerse/news/id_81879982/wirtschaft-latinos-weisen-trumps-militaerische-option-gegen-venezuela-zurueck.html", "storyUri": "deu-753256", "id": "8923173", "image": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "time": "13:55:00", "dateCrawl": "2017-08-13"}], "page": 1, "totalResults": 702, "count": 1}}}

I don't see one in Venezuela in terms of the military force.\"\n\n___\n\n12 p.m.\n\nCIA Director Mike Pompeo (pahm-PAY'-oh) says that when President Donald Trump raised the prospect of possible U.S. military action in Venezuela, he was trying \"to give the Venezuelan people hope and opportunity to create a situation where democracy can be restored.\"\n\nPompeo says Venezuela \"could very much become a risk\" to the U.S. if it descends into further chaos.\n\nThe CIA chief tells \"Fox News Sunday\" that \"the Cubans are there. The Russians are there. The Iranians, Hezbollah are there. This is something that has a risk of getting to a very, very bad place. And so, America needs to take this very seriously.\"\n\n___\n\n10:40 a.m.\n\nPresident Donald Trump's national security adviser is defending the president's statement that he's not ruling out a \"military option\" to resolve the political crisis in Venezuela.\n\nH.R. McMaster says Trump has asked his team to consider what might happen next in Venezuela.\n\nMcMaster says officials \"want to not only be able to cope with the current situation, but understand better how this crisis might evolve.\"\n\nHe says the U.S. wants to protect the Venezuelan people and \"prevent an even greater humanitarian catastrophe.\"\n\nMcMaster tells ABC's \"This Week\" that Trump \"never takes options off the table in any of these situations and what we owe him are options.\"\n\n___\n\n7:45 a.m.\n\nVice President Mike Pence is set to visit Latin America at a time of unrest in Venezuela.\n\nPence plans to meet with Colombia's president, Juan Manuel Santos, later Sunday at the start of a weeklong trip likely to be dominated by conversations about the crisis in Venezuela.\n\nColombia's Foreign Ministry has rejected President Donald Trump's statement that he wouldn't rule out a \"military option\" in response to the Venezuelan government's attempt to consolidate power.\n\nThe Colombian statement said efforts to resolve Venezuela's breakdown in democracy should be peaceful and respect its sovereignty.\n\nPence's schedule also includes stops in Argentina, Chile and Panama.\n\nCopyright 2017 The Associated Press. hoy al vicepresidente de Estados Unidos, Mike Pence, quien comienza en Colombia su primera gira por Am\u00e9rica Latina, y para cuya seguridad se han dispuestos m\u00e1s de cien agentes, informaron fuentes oficiales.\n\nDel operativo har\u00e1n parte \"cien polic\u00edas, a los que se sumar\u00e1n integrantes de la Armada Nacional as\u00ed como miembros de la Presidencia de Colombia y del Servicio Secreto de los Estados Unidos\", dijo a periodistas el comandante de Polic\u00eda Metropolitana de Cartagena, general Luis Humberto Poveda.\n\nPence, que realizar\u00e1 una gira por cuatro pa\u00edses latinoamericanos, aterrizar\u00e1 hacia las 15.00 hora local de hoy en el aeropuerto Rafael Nu\u00f1ez, de Cartagena, y posteriormente se dirigir\u00e1 a la Casa de Hu\u00e9spedes Ilustres, donde se encontrar\u00e1 con el mandatario colombiano, Juan Manuel Santos.\n\nTras el encuentro, ambos har\u00e1n una declaraci\u00f3n a los medios de comunicaci\u00f3n. Lo que se busca, explic\u00f3 el comandante de la Polic\u00eda, es que \"no se genere traumatismo en la ciudad\".\n\nTras su estad\u00eda en Colombia, que adem\u00e1s de Cartagena incluye ma\u00f1ana a Bogot\u00e1, Mike Pence viajar\u00e1 a Argentina, Chile y Panam\u00e1 como parte de su gira latinoamericana.", "timeCrawl": "17:57:00", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "extractedDates": null, "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "id": "8949879", "categories": [], "details": {}}], "page": 1, "pages": 558, "totalResults": 558}}}

El hijo del presidente venezolano, Nicol\u00e1s Maduro Guerra, ha comentado las declaraciones amenazantes. Lo anterior, del presidente estadounidense Donald Trump. Aqu\u00ed, advirtiendo sobre las consecuencias que tendr\u00eda una invasi\u00f3n militar en su pa\u00eds.\n\n\"Si se diera el supuesto negado de mancillarse el suelo patrio, los fusiles llegar\u00edan a Nueva York, se\u00f1or Trump, tomar\u00edamos la Casa Blanca, porque hasta Vietnam se quedar\u00eda peque\u00f1o\", declar\u00f3 citado por RTVE el hijo del mandatario durante una sesi\u00f3n de la Asamblea Constituyente, de la cual es miembro.\n\n\"Pero no es lo que queremos, nunca hemos sido ni seremos gente de guerra [...]. Adem\u00e1s, m\u00e9tase en sus asuntos, solucione sus problemas, se\u00f1or Trump\", precis\u00f3 Maduro Guerra.\n\nEste viernes, Trump asegur\u00f3 que Washington maneja \"muchas opciones\" respecto a la situaci\u00f3n de Venezuela y sostuvo que \"no descarto una opci\u00f3n militar\" en el pa\u00eds. \"Tenemos tropas en todo el mundo, en lugares muy, muy lejanos\" y Venezuela \"no est\u00e1 lejos\", record\u00f3 el mandatario.\n\nVarias horas despu\u00e9s, Trump se neg\u00f3 a mantener una conversaci\u00f3n telef\u00f3nica con Nicol\u00e1s Maduro debido al rechazo de EE.UU. respecto al proceso de formaci\u00f3n de la Constituyente de Venezuela.\n\nEl pasado 26 de julio, el Departamento del Tesoro de EE.UU. impuso sanciones contra 13 altos cargos del Gobierno de Venezuela, militares y la petrolera estatal venezolana PDVSA.\n\nPocos d\u00edas despu\u00e9s, ese organismo estadounidense anunci\u00f3 que Washington tambi\u00e9n sancionaba al presidente de Venezuela, Nicol\u00e1s Maduro, con el bloqueo de todos sus activos que est\u00e9n o puedan estar bajo la jurisdicci\u00f3n de EE.UU. y prohibi\u00f3 a los ciudadanos estadounidenses contraer cualquier acuerdo con ese mandatario.\n\nEl mi\u00e9rcoles, la Oficina de Control de Activos Extranjeros -- que forma parte del Departamento del Tesoro de EE.UU. -- incluy\u00f3 en su lista de Personas Especialmente Designadas (SDN, por sus siglas en ingl\u00e9s) a otros 8 oficiales venezolanos, entre los que se encuentra Ad\u00e1n Coromoto Ch\u00e1vez, hermano del difunto expresidente de Venezuela Hugo Ch\u00e1vez.", "timeCrawl": "18:00:00", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "extractedDates": [{"textStart": 1244, "date": "2017-07-26", "imp": true, "amb": false, "textEnd": 1255}], "location": null, "originalArticle": null, "date": "2017-08-13", "id": "8950276", "categories": [], "details": {}}], "page": 1, "pages": 764, "totalResults": 764}}}
